revision.text:
'''Folate targeting''' is a method utilized in [[biotechnology]] for [[drug delivery]] purposes. This [[Trojan Horse]] process, which was created by Drs. Christopher P. Leamon and Philip S. Low, involves the attachment of the [[vitamin]], folate ([[folic acid]]), to a molecule/drug to form a "folate conjugate".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Leamon CP, Low PS |title=Delivery of macromolecules into living cells: a method that exploits folate receptor endocytosis |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=88 |issue=13 |pages=5572–6 |date=July 1991 |pmid=2062838 |pmc=51919 |doi=10.1073/pnas.88.13.5572}}</ref> Based on the natural high affinity of folate for the [[folate receptor]] protein (FR), which is commonly expressed on the surface of many human [[cancer]]s, folate-drug conjugates also bind tightly to the FR and trigger cellular uptake via [[endocytosis]]. Molecules as diverse as small radiodiagnostic imaging agents to large [[DNA]] [[plasmid]] formulations have successfully been delivered inside FR-positive cells and tissues.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Leamon CP |title=Folate-targeted drug strategies for the treatment of cancer |journal=Curr Opin Investig Drugs |volume=9 |issue=12 |pages=1277–86 |date=December 2008 |pmid=19037834 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Low PS, Kularatne SA |title=Folate-targeted therapeutic and imaging agents for cancer |journal=Curr Opin Chem Biol |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=256–62 |date=June 2009 |pmid=19419901|doi=10.1016/j.cbpa.2009.03.022 }}</ref>
==Background== [[Folic acid]] (FA, folate or vitamin B<sub>9</sub>), is a vital [[nutrient]] required by all living cells for [[nucleotide]] [[biosynthesis]] and for the proper [[Metabolism|metabolic]] maintenance of 1-carbon [[Metabolic pathway|pathways]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Clifford AJ, Arjomand A, Dueker SR, Schneider PD, Buchholz BA, Vogel JS |title=The dynamics of folic acid metabolism in an adult given a small tracer dose of 14C-folic acid |journal=Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. |volume=445 |issue= |pages=239–51 |year=1998 |pmid=9781393 |doi=10.1007/978-1-4899-1959-5_15}}</ref> Aside from its cofactor role for [[intracellular]] [[enzyme]]s, FA also displays high affinity for the folate receptor (FR), a glycosylphosphatidyinositol-linked protein that captures its [[ligand]]s from the extracellular milieu and transports them inside the cell via a non-destructive, recycling [[Endosome|endosomal]] pathway.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Luhrs CA, Slomiany BL |title=A human membrane-associated folate binding protein is anchored by a glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol tail |journal=J. Biol. Chem. |volume=264 |issue=36 |pages=21446–9 |date=December 1989 |pmid=2557328 |url=http://www.jbc.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=2557328}}</ref><ref name="KamenCapdevila">{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.83.16.5983 |vauthors=Kamen BA, Capdevila A |title=Receptor-mediated folate accumulation is regulated by the cellular folate content |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=83 |issue=16 |pages=5983–7 |date=August 1986 |pmid=3461471 |pmc=386421 }}</ref> The FR is also a recognized tumor [[antigen]]/[[biomarker]].<ref name="ConeyCarayannopoulos">{{cite journal |vauthors=Coney LR, Tomassetti A, Carayannopoulos L |title=Cloning of a tumor-associated antigen: MOv18 and MOv19 antibodies recognize a folate-binding protein |journal=Cancer Res. |volume=51 |issue=22 |pages=6125–32 |date=November 1991 |pmid=1840502 |url=http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=1840502|display-authors=etal}} </ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF01052894 |vauthors=Weitman SD, Frazier KM, Kamen BA |title=The folate receptor in central nervous system malignancies of childhood |journal=J. Neurooncol. |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=107–12 |year=1994 |pmid=7861186 }}</ref><ref name="Campbell">{{cite journal |vauthors=Campbell IG, Jones TA, Foulkes WD, Trowsdale J |title=Folate-binding protein is a marker for ovarian cancer |journal=Cancer Res. |volume=51 |issue=19 |pages=5329–38 |date=October 1991 |pmid=1717147 |url=http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=1717147}}</ref> Because of this, diagnostic and therapeutic methods which exploit the FR’s function are being developed for cancer.
The FR is an emerging therapeutic target for diagnosis and treatment of cancer and chronic inflammatory diseases. Expression of the FR is selectively upregulated on certain malignant cells<ref>{{cite journal|last=Weitman|first=Steven|author2=Richard Lark |author3=Leslie Coney |author4=Daniel Fort |author5=Verna Frasca |author6=Vincent Zurawski |author7=Barton Kamen |title=Distribution of the folate receptor GP38 in normal and malignant cell lines and tissues|journal=Cancer Research|date=15 June 1992|volume=52|pages=3396–3401|pmid=1596899}}</ref> and activated macrophages.<ref name="Wei">{{cite journal|last=Wei|first=Xia |author2=Andrew Hilgenbrink |author3=Eric Matteson |author4=Michael Lockwood |author5=Ji-Xin Cheng |author6=Philip Low|title=A functional folate receptor is induced during macrophage activation and can be used to target drugs to activated macrophages|journal=Blood|date=24 October 2008|volume=113|pages=438–446|doi=10.1182/blood-2008-04-150789}}</ref> Overexpression of the FR on these types of cells is clinically significant because they designate areas where the physiological symptoms of disease are most extensive. The malignant cells indicate the presence of tumors associated with ovarian, lung, breast, kidney, brain, endometrial, and colon cancer.<ref name="Low">{{cite journal|last=Low|first=Philip|author2=Walter Henne |author3=Derek Doorneweerd |title=Discovery and development of folic-acid-based receptor targeting for imaging and therapy of cancer and inflammatory diseases|journal=Accounts of Chemical Research|date=3 April 2007|volume=41|issue=1|pages=120–129|doi=10.1021/ar7000815}}</ref> Macrophages become activated in chronic diseases such as [[rheumatoid arthritis]], [[Crohn's disease|Crohn’s disease]], [[ulcerative colitis]], [[psoriasis]], [[atherosclerosis]], [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], and most other [[Inflammation|inflammatory diseases]].<ref name="Low"/>
From a mechanistic perspective, the FR functions to concentrate [[Exogeny|exogenous]] ligands (e.g. folates and folate-drug conjugates) into the cell cytosol by endocytosis.<ref name="KamenCapdevila" /> The term [[endocytosis]] refers to the process whereby the [[Cell membrane|plasma membrane]] [[Invagination|invaginates]] and eventually forms a distinct intracellular compartment. The endocytic vesicles (endosomes) rapidly become acidified to allow the FR to release its ligand.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0167-4889(96)00041-9 |vauthors=Lee RJ, Wang S, Low PS |title=Measurement of endosome pH following folate receptor-mediated endocytosis |journal=Biochim. Biophys. Acta |volume=1312 |issue=3 |pages=237–42 |date=July 1996 |pmid=8703993 }}</ref> Afterwards, the empty FR returns to the cell surface where it can participate in another round of ligand-mediated endocytosis.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kamen BA, Wang MT, Streckfuss AJ, Peryea X, Anderson RG |title=Delivery of folates to the cytoplasm of MA104 cells is mediated by a surface membrane receptor that recycles |journal=J. Biol. Chem. |volume=263 |issue=27 |pages=13602–9 |date=September 1988 |pmid=3417674 |url=http://www.jbc.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=3417674}}</ref>
The discovery of vitamin-mediated drug targeting in plants led to the hypothesis that folate-targeted therapies could be of clinical use.<ref name="Low"/> After proteins covalently bonded to biotin were successfully transported into plant cells through receptor-mediated endocytosis, a similar technique was attempted with folate and animal cells.<ref name="Low"/> Targeted drug therapy is advantageous because it deposits the drug at the specific location where it can be most useful in treating the disease. Similarly, folate-targeted imaging therapy helps visualize areas where the FR is expressed at higher levels. With greater control over where exogenous agents are delivered, diagnostic and treatment therapies are more effective and cause fewer side effects.
==Methods of drug delivery== Specificity of folate conjugates for the FR has been shown by competition tests with free folate. When this ligand, known to bind the FR, is added in excess of the folate conjugate, it outcompetes the conjugate, indicating that the folate conjugate specifically binds the FR, and not other receptors, in the process of receptor-mediated endocytosis. Addition of an enzyme that frees the folate receptor from the cell membrane and addition of antibodies to the FR also reverse the internalization of folate conjugates, providing further evidence that folate conjugates bind the FR with specificity.<ref name="Low"/>
While some drugs and radioimaging agents are delivered to cells as folate conjugates in a one-to-one folate-to-conjugate ratio, folate-targeted liposomes allow for the delivery of larger amounts of chemotherapeutic agents.<ref name="Low"/> In this technique, drug particles are enveloped in a plasma membrane-bound vesicle. Folate is attached to polyethylene glycol bound to the phosphate heads of membrane phospholipids, thus directing the liposomes to FRs of tumor cells, by which they are engulfed.<ref name="Low"/>
==FR-positive cancer== Elevated expression of the FR occurs in many human malignancies, especially when associated with aggressively growing cancers.<ref name="Campbell"/><ref name="Toffoli1997">{{cite journal |vauthors=Toffoli G, Cernigoi C, Russo A, Gallo A, Bagnoli M, Boiocchi M |title=Overexpression of folate binding protein in ovarian cancers |journal=Int. J. Cancer |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=193–8 |date=April 1997 |pmid=9133455 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0215(19970422)74:2<193::AID-IJC10>3.0.CO;2-F}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Toffoli G, Russo A, Gallo A |title=Expression of folate binding protein as a prognostic factor for response to platinum-containing chemotherapy and survival in human ovarian cancer |journal=Int. J. Cancer |volume=79 |issue=2 |pages=121–6 |date=April 1998 |pmid=9583724 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0215(19980417)79:2<121::AID-IJC4>3.0.CO;2-V|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="Hartmann">Hartmann, L.C., Keeney, G.L., Lingle, W.L., Christianson, T.J., Varghese, B., Hillman, D., Oberg, A.L., and Low, P.S. (2007) Folate receptor overexpression is associated with poor outcome in breast cancer. International journal of cancer 121, 938-942.</ref> Recently, it was proposed that this relationship may possibly be used for prognostic purposes.<ref name="Hartmann"/> Non-mucinous ovarian cancer (the majority of ovarian cancers) was the first tumor type to be associated with FR "over-expression",<ref name="Campbell"/><ref>Miotti, S., Canevari, S., Menard, S., Mezzanzanica, D., Porro, G., Pupa, S.M., Regazzoni, M., Tagliabue, E., and Colnaghi, M.I. (1987) Characterization of human ovarian carcinoma-associated antigens defined by novel monoclonal antibodies with tumor-restricted specificity. International journal of cancer 39, 297-303.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Veggian R, Fasolato S, Ménard S |title=Immunohistochemical reactivity of a monoclonal antibody prepared against human ovarian carcinoma on normal and pathological female genital tissues |journal=Tumori |volume=75 |issue=5 |pages=510–3 |date=October 1989 |pmid=2481353 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> and it was later shown that this antigen was identical to that found on KB tumor cells and in placental tissue.<ref name="ConeyCarayannopoulos" /><ref name="Campbell"/> Several studies confirmed that ~80-90% of ovarian tumors over-express the FR.<ref name="Toffoli1997"/><ref name="Parker">{{cite journal |vauthors=Parker N, Turk MJ, Westrick E, Lewis JD, Low PS, Leamon CP |title=Folate receptor expression in carcinomas and normal tissues determined by a quantitative radioligand binding assay |journal=Anal. Biochem. |volume=338 |issue=2 |pages=284–93 |date=March 2005 |pmid=15745749 |doi=10.1016/j.ab.2004.12.026 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003-2697(05)00006-0}}</ref><ref name="Wu">{{cite journal |author1=Wu M. |author2=Gunning W. |author3=Ratnam M. | year = 1999 | title = Expression of folate receptor type a in relation to cell type, malignancy, and differentiation in ovary, uterus, and cervix | url = | journal = Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 775–783 }}</ref> Other gynecological cancers also over-express the receptor<ref name="Wu"/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1074/jbc.274.16.11086 |vauthors=Maziarz KM, Monaco HL, Shen F, Ratnam M |title=Complete mapping of divergent amino acids responsible for differential ligand binding of folate receptors alpha and beta |journal=J. Biol. Chem. |volume=274 |issue=16 |pages=11086–91 |date=April 1999 |pmid=10196192 |url=http://www.jbc.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=10196192}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Allard JE, Risinger JI, Morrison C |title=Overexpression of folate binding protein is associated with shortened progression-free survival in uterine adenocarcinomas |journal=Gynecol. Oncol. |volume=107 |issue=1 |pages=52–7 |date=October 2007 |pmid=17582475 |doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2007.05.018 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0090-8258(07)00359-9|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dainty LA, Risinger JI, Morrison C |title=Overexpression of folate binding protein and mesothelin are associated with uterine serous carcinoma |journal=Gynecol. Oncol. |volume=105 |issue=3 |pages=563–70 |date=June 2007 |pmid=17400285 |doi=10.1016/j.ygyno.2006.10.063 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0090-8258(06)00894-8|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">21</ref> as well as pediatric ependymal brain tumors, mesothelioma, and breast, colon, renal and lung tumors.<ref name="Parker"/> The FR may also be found associated with cancer, particularly when related to myeloid leukemia and perhaps head and neck carcinomas.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/1097-0142(19940501)73:9<2432::AID-CNCR2820730929>3.0.CO;2-S |vauthors=Ross JF, Chaudhuri PK, Ratnam M |title=Differential regulation of folate receptor isoforms in normal and malignant tissues in vivo and in established cell lines. Physiologic and clinical implications |journal=Cancer |volume=73 |issue=9 |pages=2432–43 |date=May 1994 |pmid=7513252 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ross JF, Wang H, Behm FG |title=Folate receptor type beta is a neutrophilic lineage marker and is differentially expressed in myeloid leukemia |journal=Cancer |volume=85 |issue=2 |pages=348–57 |date=January 1999 |pmid=10023702 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0142(19990115)85:2<348::AID-CNCR12>3.0.CO;2-4|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Taken together, the total number of tumors that express the FR is very large; therefore, FR-targeted strategies could have significant impact on cancer treatment for patients diagnosed with FR-positive disease.
==Diagnostics== The FR is expressed on many different types of malignant tissues and in large quantities.<ref name="Parker"/> But, not all human cancers within a particular indication will express the FR. Because novel FR-targeted therapies are now being tested clinically,<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Konner JA, Ahmed S, Gerst S, Vander Els N, Pezzuli S, Sabbatini P, Hensley M, Dupont J, Tew W, Aghajanian C |title=Phase I study of MORAb-003, a humanized anti-folate receptor-alpha monoclonal antibody, in platinum resistant ovarian cancer |journal=J Clin Oncol |volume=24 |issue=18S |pages=5027 |date=June 20, 2006 |url=http://meeting.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/abstract/24/18_suppl/5027}} </ref><ref name="Leamon2007">{{cite journal |vauthors=Leamon CP, Reddy JA, Vlahov IR |title=Preclinical antitumor activity of a novel folate-targeted dual drug conjugate |journal=Mol. Pharm. |volume=4 |issue=5 |pages=659–67 |year=2007 |pmid=17874843 |doi=10.1021/mp070049c|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Reddy07>{{cite journal |vauthors=Reddy JA, Dorton R, Westrick E |title=Preclinical evaluation of EC145, a folate-vinca alkaloid conjugate |journal=Cancer Res. |volume=67 |issue=9 |pages=4434–42 |date=May 2007 |pmid=17483358 |doi=10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-07-0033 |url=http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17483358|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Sausville07>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sausville E, LoRusso P, Quinn M, Forman K, Leamon C, Morganstern D, Bever S, Messmann R |title=A phase I study of EC145 administered weeks 1 and 3 of a 4-week cycle in patients with refractory solid tumors |journal=J Clin Oncol |volume=25 |issue=18S |pages=2577 |date=June 20, 2007 |url=http://meeting.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/abstract/25/18_suppl/2577}}</ref><ref name=Covello08>{{cite conference |vauthors=Covello KL, Flefleh C, Menard K, Wiebesiek A, Mcglinchey K, Wen ML, Westhouse R, Reddy JA, Vlahov IR, Hunt J |title=Preclinical pharmacology of epothilone-folate conjugate BMS-753493, a tumor-targeting agent selected for clinical development |booktitle=Proceedings of the 99th Annual Meeting of AACR |date=April 12–16, 2008 |location=San Diego, CA |id=Abstract #2326 |url=http://www.aacrmeetingabstracts.org/cgi/content/meeting_abstract/2008/1_Annual_Meeting/2326|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Messmann R, Amato R, Hernandez-McClain J, Conley B, Rogers H, Lu J, Low P, Bever S, Morgenstern D |title=A phase II study of FolateImmune (EC90 with GP1–0100 adjuvant followed by EC17) with low dose cytokines interleukin-2 (IL-2) and interferon-α (IFN-α) in patients with refractory or metastatic cancer |journal=J Clin Oncol |volume=25 |issue=18S |pages=13516 |date=June 20, 2007 |url=http://meeting.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/abstract/25/18_suppl/13516}}</ref> having the ability to screen patients for FR-positive disease could certainly increase the efficiency of and decrease the time for clinical investigations of these novel agents.
Currently, there are two principal methods that have been utilized for assessing a patient’s "FR status". These include an invasive tissue-based immunohistochemical assay, and a non-invasive radiodiagnostic approach. The latter method is now being tested clinically using <sup>99m</sup>Tc-EC20.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Leamon CP, Parker MA, Vlahov IR |title=Synthesis and biological evaluation of EC20: a new folate-derived, (99m)Tc-based radiopharmaceutical |journal=Bioconjug. Chem. |volume=13 |issue=6 |pages=1200–10 |year=2002 |pmid=12440854 |doi=10.1021/bc0200430|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Reddy JA, Xu LC, Parker N, Vetzel M, Leamon CP |title=Preclinical evaluation of (99m)Tc-EC20 for imaging folate receptor-positive tumors |journal=J. Nucl. Med. |volume=45 |issue=5 |pages=857–66 |date=May 2004 |pmid=15136637 |url=http://jnm.snmjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15136637}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fisher RE, Siegel BA, Edell SL |title=Exploratory study of 99mTc-EC20 imaging for identifying patients with folate receptor-positive solid tumors |journal=J. Nucl. Med. |volume=49 |issue=6 |pages=899–906 |date=June 2008 |pmid=18483093 |doi=10.2967/jnumed.107.049478 |url=http://jnm.snmjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18483093|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Folate-targeted chemotherapy== To date, four distinct FA-drug conjugates have entered clinical trials for the treatment of cancer:
''[[Vintafolide]] (EC145)'' represents a novel water-soluble FA conjugate of the powerful microtubule destabilizing agent, desacetylvinblastine monohydrazide (DAVLBH; a derivative of the natural product, [[vinblastine]]).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Leamon CP, Reddy JA, Vlahov IR |title=Comparative preclinical activity of the folate-targeted Vinca alkaloid conjugates EC140 and EC145 |journal=Int. J. Cancer |volume=121 |issue=7 |pages=1585–92 |date=October 2007 |pmid=17551919 |doi=10.1002/ijc.22853|display-authors=etal}}</ref> EC145 was found to produce marked anti-tumor effect against well-established, subcutaneous FR-positive [[Patient derived tumor xenografts|tumor xenografts]] using well tolerated regimens.<ref name=Reddy07/> EC145 also represents the first FA-drug conjugate to be evaluated in clinical trials,<ref name=Sausville07/> and it is currently (2009) being tested in a multi-national randomized Phase 2b trial in combination with pegylated liposomal doxorubicin ([[Doxil]]).
''EC0225'' represents the "first in class" multi-drug, FA-targeted agent to be reported. It is a molecule constructed with a single FA moiety and extended by a hydrophilic peptide-based spacer that is, in turn, linked to ''Vinca'' alkaloid and mitomycin units via 2 distinct disulfide-containing linkers.<ref name="Leamon2007" /> Animals bearing well-established human tumor xenografts were found to completely respond to EC0225 therapy with dosing regimens that were approximately 3-fold less intensive to that required for EC145. A Phase 1 trial for EC0225 is in progress.
''BMS-753493'' is a molecule born from a collaboration between scientists at Endocyte Inc. and Bristol Myers Squibb (BMS). It represents a FA conjugate that was constructed with a semi-synthetic analog of Epothilone A.<ref name=Covello08/> BMS-753493 is currently being evaluated for safety and efficacy in Phase 2 clinical trials sponsored by BMS.
''EC0489'' is the latest folate-targeted chemotherapeutic to enter clinical trials sponsored by Endocyte. This molecule is actually a derivative of EC145 (see above) that was designed to have limited non-specific clearance properties through the liver. By reducing hepatic clearance, less drug will transit through the biliary excretion route; as a consequence, less off-target toxicities (predicted from preclinical tests) are expected.
==Activated macrophage targeting== Macrophages are the human body’s first line of defense against invading pathogens. Normally, they circulate in the bloodstream in a dormant state, but at a site of inflammation due to injury or autoimmune disease, they become activated, changing shape and expressing different cell surface markers.<ref name="Wei"/> The upregulated expression of the FR makes activated macrophages a useful tool in folate-targeted therapy. Activated, TNF-alpha producing macrophages express the beta isoform of the FR, and they are targetable with folate conjugates ''in vivo''. For example, <sup>99m</sup>Tc-EC20 was reported to concentrate in the livers, spleens and arthritic extremities of adjuvant-induced arthritic rats via a folate-dependent mechanism.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Turk MJ, Breur GJ, Widmer WR |title=Folate-targeted imaging of activated macrophages in rats with adjuvant-induced arthritis |journal=Arthritis Rheum. |volume=46 |issue=7 |pages=1947–55 |date=July 2002 |pmid=12124880 |doi=10.1002/art.10405|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Development of folate-drug conjugates for inflammation therapy is underway.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Yi YS, Ayala-López W, Kularatne SA, Low PS |title=Folate-targeted hapten immunotherapy of adjuvant-induced arthritis: comparison of hapten potencies |journal=Mol. Pharm.|volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=1228–36 |date=July 2009 |pmid=19374407 |doi=10.1021/mp900070b}}</ref> It is expected that ailments which harbor activated macrophages (such as arthritis, psoriasis and inflammatory bowel disease) may someday be treatable with folate-targeted medicines.
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Refbegin}} *K.Viveksarathi et al., Design and in vitro Evaluation of Gastroretentive Floating Drug Delivery System of Rosigilitazone Maleate.J.Pharm.Sci.&Res. Vol.5(8),2013, 166-170. http://jpsr.pharmainfo.in/Documents/Volumes/vol5issue08/jpsr05081303.pdf *K.Viveksarathi et al.,Formulation Development and In-Vitro Evaluation of Gastroretentive Floating tablets of Atenolol. Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences & Research;2011, Vol.3(12),p1632. http://www.jpsr.pharmainfo.in/Documents/Volumes/vol3Issue12/jpsr%2003111207.pdf *Amato, R.J., Fagbeyiro, B., Messmann, R., and Low, P.S. (2005) Phase I trial of EC90 (keyhole-limpet hemocyanin fluorescein isothiocyanate conjugate) with GPI-0100 adjuvant followed by EC17 (Folate-Fluorescein Isothiocyanate Conjugate) in Patients (pts) with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (MRCC). Journal of Clinical Oncology 23, 2590. <!-- Can't find an article with this title in 2005 at http://jco.ascopubs.org/ or with google scholar --> {{Refend}}
==External links==
[[Category:Biotechnology]]

revision.text:
[[File:傅達仁 20171120.jpg|thumb|Fu in November 2017]] '''Fu Da-ren''' ({{zh|t=傅達仁}}; 3 April 1933 – 7 June 2018) was a Taiwanese television presenter who received a [[Golden Bell Award]] in 1980.
Fu Da-ren was raised in an orphanage established by [[Soong Mei-ling]] after his father, [[Republic of China Army]] Major General {{ill|Fu Chung-kuei|zh|傅忠貴}} (1885－1938), was killed in action during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]].<ref>{{cite news | first1=Howard |last1=Lin |title=Crowds mark 111th anniversary of Madame Chiang Kai-shek's birth |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/search/200803190036.aspx |accessdate=7 June 2018 |agency=Central News Agency |date=19 March 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hsu |first1=Chloe |last2=Hsu |first2=Elizabeth |title=Lee Teng-hui's benefits as ex-president may be stripped |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/search/201508210021.aspx |accessdate=7 June 2018 |agency=Central News Agency |date=21 August 2015}}</ref>
Several catchphrases familiar to athletes and sports fans in Taiwan were popularized by Fu during his broadcasting career.<ref>{{cite news |title=EDITORIAL: Remembering a broadcast legend |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2018/06/13/2003694778 |accessdate=17 June 2018 |work=Taipei Times |date=13 June 2018}}</ref> Fu was Christian.<ref name="peaceatlast">{{cite news |last1=Lai |first1=Julianna |title=Peace at last: Frank Fu Da-ren’s parting gift |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2018/07/10/2003696414 |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=Taipei Times |date=10 July 2018}}</ref>
In later life, Fu was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, and actively supported euthanasia.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ex-sports commentator advocates for euthanasia |url=https://chinapost.nownews.com/20161208-16383 |accessdate=7 June 2018 |work=China Post |date=8 December 2016}}</ref> His family researched options for assisted suicide, but found that although the End of Life Option Act made the procedure legal in California, no hospital in Los Angeles would accept Fu's medical records.<ref name="peaceatlast"/> He traveled to Switzerland in November 2017 to join [[Dignitas (Swiss non-profit organisation)|Dignitas]], an organization that provides assisted suicide to its members.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lung |first1=Po-an |last2=Liu |first2=Kuan-lin |title=Former sports announcer joins Swiss assisted-suicide organization |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/search/201711100013.aspx |accessdate=7 June 2018 |agency=Central News Agency |date=10 November 2017}}</ref> Days later, Fu chose not to die by euthanasia,<ref>{{cite news|first1=Po-an |last1=Lung |first2=Elizabeth |last2=Hsu |title=Sports journalist cancels euthanasia plan |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/search/201711190018.aspx |accessdate=7 June 2018 |work=China Times |publisher=Central News Agency |date=19 November 2017 |archiveurl=https://chinapost.nownews.com/20171120-161645 |archivedate=20 November 2017}}</ref> and received a visit from [[Tsai Ing-wen]] upon his return to Taiwan.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shih |first1=Hsiu-chuan |title=President Tsai meets with Fu Da-ren |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/search/201711200032.aspx |accessdate=7 June 2018 |work=China Post |date=20 November 2017 |archiveurl=https://chinapost.nownews.com/20171121-161806 |archivedate=21 November 2017}}</ref> In May 2018, Fu flew to Zurich and underwent euthanasia on 7 June 2018, aged 85.<ref name="peaceatlast"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Lee |first1=Chin-wei |last2=Chang |first2=S.C. |title=Former sports anchor Fu Da-ren ends life by assisted suicide |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/search/201806070023.aspx |accessdate=7 June 2018 |agency=Central News Agency |date=7 June 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fu, Da-ren}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Taiwanese television presenters]] [[Category:Deaths by euthanasia]] [[Category:Euthanasia activists]] [[Category:Taiwanese activists]] [[Category:Taiwanese Christians]] [[Category:Association football commentators]] [[Category:Basketball announcers]] [[Category:Baseball announcers]]

revision.text:
{{otheruses}} {{Infobox film | name = Gates of Heaven | image = gatesofheaven.jpg | image size = | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Errol Morris]] | producer = Errol Morris | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | narrator = | starring = Floyd McClure
Cal Harberts
Florence Rasmussen | music = | cinematography = Ned Burgess | editing = Errol Morris | studio = | distributor = [[New Yorker Films]] | released = {{Film date|1980|10|19|US|}} | runtime = 83 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Gates of Heaven''''' is a 1978 [[documentary film]] by [[Errol Morris]] about the [[pet cemetery]] business. It was made when Morris was unknown and did much to launch his career. ==Synopsis== The film, like Morris' other works, is unnarrated and the stories are told purely through interviews. It is divided into two main sections. The first concerns Floyd "Mac" McClure and his lifelong quest to allow pets to have a graceful burial. McClure's business associates and his competitor, a manager of a [[rendering (industrial)|rendering plant]], are interviewed. Eventually the business fails and the 450 animals have to be dug up and transported to the Bubbling Well Pet Memorial Park. This operation is run by John "Cal" Harberts and his two sons. This business is far more successful, and continues to operate today, run by Cal's son Dan Harberts.[http://www.metroactive.com/bohemian/05.31.06/bubbling-well-0622.html Three Feet Under. Metroactive. Retrieved November 28, 2010] ==Critical reception== Noted director [[Werner Herzog]] pledged that he would eat the shoe he was wearing if Morris' film on this improbable subject was completed and shown in a public theater. When the film was released Herzog lived up to his wager and the consumption of his footwear was made into the short film ''[[Werner Herzog Eats His Shoe]]''. ''Gates of Heaven'' launched Morris' career and is now considered a classic. In 1991, [[Roger Ebert]] named it one of the ten best films ever made.[http://www.rogerebert.com/rogers-journal/ten-greatest-films-of-all-time Ten Greatest Films of All Time. Roger Ebert's Journal. Retrieved Mar 1, 2014] Roger Ebert wrote that the film is an "underground legend," and in 1997 put it in his list of [[The Great Movies]].{{cite news | url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19971109/REVIEWS08/401010320/1023 | title=Gates of Heaven | publisher=''[[Chicago Sun Times]]'' |date=November 9, 1997 | first= | last= | accessdate =2008-03-11}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} *[http://www.errolmorris.com/film/gates.html Gates of Heaven] from [[Errol Morris|ErrolMorris.com]] *{{imdb title|id=0077598|title=Gates of Heaven}} * {{Allmovie title|19293|Gates of Heaven}} *{{Rotten-tomatoes|id=gates_of_heaven_1980|title=Gates of Heaven}} *[http://www.bubbling-well.com/index.shtml Bubbling Well Pet Memorial Park]. {{Errol Morris|state=collapsed}} [[Category:1978 films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:POV (TV series) films]] [[Category:Films directed by Errol Morris]] [[Category:Films produced by Errol Morris]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:Documentary films about death]] [[Category:Animals and humans]] [[Category:Films featuring pets]] [[Category:Animal cemeteries]]

revision.comment: /* Overview */
revision.text:
{{short description|The application of information science methods in geography, cartography, and geosciences}} {{distinguish|Geomatics}} {{refimprove|date=October 2015|reason=References are very lacking, and the ones that are there give no page numbers or other verification aids}} '''Geoinformatics''' is the science and the technology which develops and uses [[information science]] infrastructure to address the problems of [[geography]], [[cartography]], [[geosciences]] and related branches of science and engineering.
==Overview==
Geoinformatics has been described as "the science and technology dealing with the structure and character of spatial information, its capture, its classification and qualification, its storage, processing, portrayal and dissemination, including the infrastructure necessary to secure optimal use of this information"<ref>P.L.N. Raju, Fundamentals of Geographic Information Systems</ref> or "the art, science or technology dealing with the acquisition, storage, processing production, presentation and dissemination of geoinformation".<ref>M. Ehlers (2008) Geoinformatics and digital earth initiatives: a German perspective, International Journal of Digital Earth, 1:1, 17-30, DOI: 10.1080/17538940701781975</ref>
[[Geomatics]] is a similarly used term which encompasses geoinformatics, but geomatics focuses more so on [[surveying]]. Geoinformatics has at its core the technologies supporting the processes of acquiring, analyzing and visualizing spatial data. Both geomatics and geoinformatics include and rely heavily upon the theory and practical implications of [[geodesy]].
Geography and earth science increasingly rely on digital spatial data acquired from remotely sensed images analyzed by [[geographical information systems]] (GIS) and visualized on paper or the computer screen.<ref>Bouloucos and Brown, ITC Courses in Remote Sensing, GIS and Photogrammetry</ref>
Geoinformatics combines geospatial analysis and modeling, development of geospatial databases, information systems design, human-computer interaction and both wired and wireless networking technologies. Geoinformatics uses [[geocomputation]] and [[geovisualization]] for analyzing [[geoinformation]].
Branches of geoinformatics include:
<gallery> Image:Hereford_Mappa_Mundi_1300.jpg|[[Cartography]] Image:Geoid_height_red_blue.png|[[Geodesy]] Image:GPS_Satellite_NASA_art-iif.jpg|[[Global Navigation Satellite System]]s Image:Alpha2000.jpg|[[Photogrammetry]] Image:Island_of_Hawai'i_-_Landsat_mosaic.jpg|[[Remote Sensing]] File:Example_krig.png|[[Spatial Analysis]] Image:Worldwind.png|[[Web mapping]] </gallery>
==Research==
Research in this field is used to support global and local environmental, energy and security programs. The Geographic Information Science and Technology group of [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] is supported by various government departments and agencies including the [[United States Department of Energy]]. It is currently the only group in the [[United States Department of Energy National Laboratories|United States Department of Energy National Laboratory System]] to focus on advanced theory and application research in this field. There are also a lot of interdiscipline research involved in geoinformatics fields including computer science, information technology, software engineering, biogeography, geography, conservation, architecture, spatial analysis and reinformacement learning.
==Applications==
Many fields benefit from geoinformatics, including urban planning and land use management, in-car navigation systems, virtual globes, public health, local and national gazetteer management, environmental modeling and analysis, military, transport network planning and management, agriculture, meteorology and climate change, oceanography and coupled ocean and atmosphere modelling, business location planning, architecture and archeological reconstruction, telecommunications, criminology and crime simulation, aviation, biodiversity conservation and maritime transport. The importance of the spatial dimension in assessing, monitoring and modelling various issues and problems related to sustainable management of natural resources is recognized all over the world. Geoinformatics becomes very important technology to decision-makers across a wide range of disciplines, industries, commercial sector, environmental agencies, local and national government, research, and academia, national survey and mapping organisations, International organisations, United Nations, emergency services, public health and epidemiology, crime mapping, transportation and infrastructure, information technology industries, GIS consulting firms, environmental management agencies), tourist industry, utility companies, market analysis and e-commerce, mineral exploration, etc. Many government and non government agencies started to use spatial data for managing their day-to-day activities.
==See also== *[[Geographic information science]] *[[Geographical information systems]] *[[Geographic information systems software]] *[[GeoComputation]] *[[International Coalition for GeoInformatics]] (iGeoInfo) *[[Cartography]] *[[Symbiosis Institute of Geoinformatics]] *[[Urban informatics]] *[[Crowdmapping]]
== References ==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.opengeospatial.org Open Geospatial Consortium] *[http://www.icaci.org International Cartographic Association (ICA)], the world body for mapping and GIScience professionals * [http://www.isprs.org International Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing] * [http://www.iugg.org/ International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics (IUGG)]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Earth sciences]] [[Category:Geographical technology]] [[Category:Information science by discipline]] [[Category:Cartography]] [[Category:Geomatics]] [[Category:Computational fields of study]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2015}}
{{Infobox D&D creature |name=Gray ooze |image=[[Image:Gray Ooze.JPG|200px]] |alignment=Neutral |type=Ooze |subtype= |source= |first= |mythical= |based= }} In the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' [[fantasy]] [[role-playing game]], the '''gray ooze''' is an [[Ooze (Dungeons & Dragons)|ooze]]. It resembles a thick, [[viscous]] puddle of gray sludge, roughly 6 to 8 inches thick and up to 14 feet across, and often closely resembles wet stone or an amorphous rock formation.
==Publication history== The gray ooze first appeared in the [[Dungeons & Dragons (1974)|original ''Dungeons & Dragons'' set]] (1974), and also appeared in the supplement ''[[Eldritch Wizardry]]'' (1976).
The gray ooze appeared in the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set|D&D Basic Set]]'' (1977, 1981, 1983) and ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Rules Cyclopedia]]'' (1991).
The gray ooze appeared in first edition ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' in the original ''[[Monster Manual]]'' (1977).<ref>[[Gary Gygax|Gygax, Gary]]. ''[[Monster Manual]]'' (TSR, 1977)</ref>
The gray ooze appeared in second edition ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' in ''Monstrous Compendium Volume One'' (1989),<ref>[[David Cook (game designer)|Cook, David]], et al. ''Monstrous Compendium Volume One'' ([[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], 1989)</ref> reprinted in the ''Monstrous Manual'' (1993) under the "ooze" entry.<ref>Stewart, Doug, ed. ''[[Monster Manual|Monstrous Manual]]'' ([[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], 1993)</ref> The psionic variant of the grey ooze appeared in ''[[The Complete Psionics Handbook]]'' (1991). The creature was expanded on in ''[[Dragon (magazine)|Dragon]]'' Annual #4 (1999).<ref>Richards, Jonathan M. "Ecology of the Gray Ooze: Ooze There?" Dragon Annual #4 (TSR, 1999)</ref>
The gray ooze appeared in the third edition ''Monster Manual'' (2000) under the "ooze" entry,<ref>[[Skip Williams|Williams, Skip]], [[Jonathan Tweet]], and [[Monte Cook]]. ''[[Monster Manual]]'' ([[Wizards of the Coast]], 2000)</ref> and the version 3.5 ''Monster Manual'' (2003).
==Characteristics and habits== Gray oozes, like most oozes, are underground dwelling, mindless scavengers who drag themselves around caves and sewers and absorb and digest whatever they find. Unlike some other oozes, it cannot move on ceilings or walls, and hence is left to slide its way along floors. The gray ooze attacks by striking like a snake until prey is either dead or unconscious, and it then moves on top of them to digest them from within. It is immune to cold and fire. The gray ooze's acidic secretions corrode metal at an alarming rate, and in addition to giving the creature a method of destroying opponent's weapons and armor, blacksmiths also sometimes use jarred gray oozes to meld ore into the right shape. Gray oozes reproduce by breaking small driplets off of themselves after a meal, which later grow into gray oozes themselves.
Gray oozes cannot speak.
They are [[Alignment (Dungeons & Dragons)#Neutral|neutral]] in alignment.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{D&D topics}}
[[Category:Dungeons & Dragons creatures]] [[Category:Fictional amorphous creatures]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox court case | name = In re Quinlan | court = [[New Jersey Supreme Court]] | image = Seal of New Jersey.svg | imagesize = | imagelink = | imagealt = | caption = | full name = In the matter of Karen Quinlan, an alleged incompetent | date decided = March 31, 1976 | citations = [[Case citation|70 N.J. 10; 355 A.2d 647]] (1976) | transcripts = | judges = [[Richard J. Hughes|Chief Justice Hughes]], Justices Mountain, [[Mark Sullivan (jurist)|Sullivan]], [[Morris Pashman|Pashman]], [[Robert L. Clifford|Clifford]] and Schreiber and Judge Conford | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = '''Majority:''' Hughes (unanimous) | keywords = }}
'''''In re Quinlan''''' (70 N.J. 10, 355 A.2d 647 (NJ 1976)) was a landmark<ref>http://www.libraryindex.com/pages/582/Court-End-Life-RIGHT-PRIVACY-KAREN-ANN-QUINLAN.html</ref> 1975 court case in the United States in which the parents of a woman who was kept alive by artificial means were allowed to order her removal from artificial ventilation.<ref>http://law.jrank.org/pages/3250/In-Matter-Karen-Ann-Quinlan-1975.html</ref><ref>http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FSL/is_n4_v67/ai_20972811/</ref>
==Karen Ann Quinlan== <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[File:KarenAnnQuinlan.jpg|thumb|Quinlan's high school graduation photo in 1972]] -->
{{Main article|Karen Ann Quinlan}} Karen Ann Quinlan was 21 years old in 1975. After a night of drinking alcohol and ingesting [[tranquilizer]]s, Quinlan passed out and ceased breathing for two 15-minute periods. After it was determined that she was in a [[persistent vegetative state]], her father, Joseph Quinlan, wished to remove her from the [[medical ventilator]]. Quinlan's primary physician and the hospital both refused.
==Legal case==
Quinlan's father retained attorneys Paul W. Armstrong, a Morris County, New Jersey, Legal Aid attorney, and James M. Crowley, an associate at the New York City law firm of Shearman & Sterling with degrees in theology and Church law, and filed suit in the [[New Jersey Superior Court]] in [[Morris County, New Jersey]], on September 12, 1975,<ref>"Couple Files Suit To End Life", ''Deseret News'' (Salt Lake City), September 13, 1975, p1</ref> to be appointed as Quinlan's [[legal guardian]] so that he could act on her behalf. Armstrong would later become involved in the [[Cruzan v. Director, Missouri Department of Health|Nancy Cruzan case]] and later still become a judge.<ref>[http://www.nj.com/somerset/index.ssf/2015/05/quinlan_case_attorney_respected_judge_leaving_benc.html Judge who fought landmark right-to-die cases leaves Somerset bench]</ref> Crowley is, as of 2017, legal counsel and advisor to several [[Holy See|Vatican]]-related entities.
The Court denied his request on November 10, 1975.<ref>"Must Choose Life, Judge Says in Quinlan Decision", ''Milwaukee Journal'', November 11, 1975, p8</ref> Joseph Quinlan appealed the decision to the [[Supreme Court of New Jersey]], which on March 31, 1976, held that he could authorize the cessation of ventilation; and that [[Saint Clare's Hospital at Boonton Township|Saint Clare's Hospital]] was bound to proceed with this order.
==Aftermath==
After being removed from the ventilator, Quinlan continued to breathe until her death, in 1985, from [[pneumonia]].<ref>McFadden, Robert (June 12, 1985). "Karen Ann Quinlan, 31, Dies; Focus of '76 Right to Die Case". New York Times.</ref>
The [[autopsy]] of Quinlan's brain found extensive damage to the bilateral [[thalamus]].<ref>http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/330/21/1469</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Betancourt v. Trinitas Hospital]]'': another New Jersey case on end of life care
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://law.jrank.org/pages/3250/In-Matter-Karen-Ann-Quinlan-1975.html American Law and Legal Information on Karen Ann Quinlan] * [http://euthanasia.procon.org/sourcefiles/In_Re_Quinlan.pdf Full text of decision]
{{EthicsCases}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:In Re Quinlan}} [[Category:New Jersey state case law]] [[Category:1976 in United States case law]] [[Category:1976 in New Jersey]] [[Category:Morris County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Medical controversies in the United States]] [[Category:Euthanasia in the United States]] [[Category:Euthanasia law]]

revision.comment: /* See also */ id solut
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} In [[physics]], '''interaction energy''' is the contribution to the total [[energy]] that is caused by an [[interaction]] between the objects being considered.
The interaction energy usually depends on the relative position of the objects. For example, <math>Q_1 Q_2 / (4 \pi \epsilon_0 \Delta r)</math> is the [[electrostatics|electrostatic]] interaction energy between two objects with charges <math>Q_1</math>, <math>Q_2</math>.
==Supermolecular interaction energy== A straightforward approach for evaluating the interaction energy is to calculate the difference between the energies of isolated objects and their assembly. In the case of two objects, ''A'' and ''B'', the interaction energy can be written as:
<math>\Delta E_{int} = E(A,B) - \left( E(A) + E(B) \right)</math>,
where <math>E(A)</math> and <math>E(B)</math> are the energies of the isolated objects (monomers), and <math>E(A,B)</math> the energy of their interacting assembly (dimer).
For larger system, consisting of ''N'' objects, this procedure can be generalized to provide a total many-body interaction energy:
<math>\Delta E_{int} = E(A_{1}, A_{2}, .., A_{N}) - \sum_{i=1}^{N} E(A_{i})</math>.
By calculating the energies for monomers, dimers, trimers, etc., in an N-object system, a complete set of two-, three-, and up to N-body interaction energies can be derived.
The supermolecular approach has an important disadvantage in that the final interaction energy is usually much smaller than the total energies from which it is calculated, and therefore contains a much larger relative uncertainty. In the case where energies are derived from quantum chemical calculations using finite atom centered basis functions, [[basis set superposition error]]s can also contribute some degree of artificial stabilisation.
==See also== * [[Energy]] * [[Force]] * [[Interaction]] * [[Ideal solution]] * [[Perturbation theory (quantum mechanics)]] * [[Potential]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Interaction Energy}} [[Category:Interaction]] [[Category:Energy (physics)]]
