revision.text:
{{essay-like|date=June 2018}} {{use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Joe Campos Torres | image = Joecampostorres.jpg | image_upright = 1.0 | alt = | caption = | birth_name = José Campos Torres | birth_date = {{Birth date|1953|12|20}} | birth_place = [[Houston|Houston, Texas]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1977|05|05|1953|12|20}} | death_place = Houston, Texas | death_cause = [[Drowning]] | body_discovered = Floating in the [[Buffalo Bayou]]
Houston, Texas | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship = American | occupation = Glass contractor | years_active = | known_for = Police murder victim | parents = {{unbulleted list|Margaret Campos Torres
José Luna Torres}} | relatives = {{unbulleted list|Janie Torres (sister)}} | website = [https://www.facebook.com/solidaritywalkhouston/ Solidarity Walk Houston] | foot notes = | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{flagu|United States|name=United States|1960|size=21px}} | branch = [[File:United States Department of the Army Seal.svg|23px|United States Army seal]] [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = 1974–1976 | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = [[Houston National Cemetery]]{{cite web|last1=Administration|first1=National Cemetery|title=Nationwide Gravesite Locator|url=https://gravelocator.cem.va.gov/index.html|website=gravelocator.cem.va.gov|publisher=United States of America, Veterans Administration|accessdate=4 December 2017}} | placeofburial_coordinates = {{Coord|29.931250|-95.450472|dim:255_region:US-TX}} | rank = [[Image:Army-USA-OR-02.svg|20px]] [[Private (rank)#United States|Private]] | unit = | battles_label = Era | battles = [[Vietnam War]] }} }} '''José Campos Torres''' (December 20, 1953 – May 5, 1977) was a 23-year-old [[Mexican-American]] and [[Vietnam veteran]] who was ruthlessly beaten by several [[White people|White]] [[Houston Police Department]] (HPD) officers that subsequently led to his death. He was [[assault]]ed by a group of on-duty police officers after being arrested for [[Disorderly conduct#United States|disorderly conduct]] at a bar in Houston's Mexican-American [[East End, Houston|East End]] neighborhood. The officers [[conviction|convicted]] for the death of Torres, at the state level, received minimal sentencing; 1 year [[probation]] and a $1 fine. Torres' murder and sentencing sparked community outrage and lead to multiple community [[protest]]s, with one gathering escalating to a [[riot]]. His death lead to [[advocacy]] based {{nowrap|[[Nonprofit organization|non-profits]]}} and HPD official's negotiations leading to the addition of policies addressing {{nowrap|police-community}} racial relations. After Torres' arrest at the bar, the officers took him to the city jail for booking. But, he was struck so brutally that authorities refused to book him into the jail. Instead the police officers were ordered, by a supervisor, to take Torres to a local hospital for immediate medical treatment. The officers did not comply with the supervisor's order. Three days later, on [[Mother's Day]], Sunday, May 8, 1977 his dead body was found severely beaten and floating in the [[Buffalo Bayou]], a creek on the outskirts of downtown Houston. Terry W. Denson and Steven Orlando two of the arresting officers were [[Criminal charge|charged]] with murder following the discovery of Torres' body. Three other officers were fired from the HPD by Police Chief B.G. Bond, but no criminal charges were brought against the fired officers. A rookie officer who was present at the scenes of Torres' [[torture]] and drowning was a key witness for the prosecution. Denson and Orlando were convicted for Torres' death and found guilty of [[negligent homicide]] (a [[misdemeanor]]), sentenced to one year of [[probation]] and a one dollar fine. The all white jury minimized criminal convictions and sentencing sparked community outrage leading to multiple protests{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2017_03710|title=Protests Against Police Brutality (1977)|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1977|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} and the [[Murder of Joe Campos Torres#Moody Park Riot|1978 Moody Park Riot]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2017_03709|title=Moody Park Riot (1978)|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1978|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} The investigation of Torres' murder proved controversial. Following the State of Texas convictions of the two former officers, the Torres case was reviewed at the federal level by the [[U.S. Department of Justice]]. Which led to three of the officer's federal convictions, for violating Torres' [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]]. Torres' murder generated significant newspaper articles across the United States, while national televised [[mainstream media]] has no history of 'special' reports nor any episodes reporting the circumstances leading to his murder. Newspaper outlets initially focusing on his assault and drowning soon turned their attention to the historic [[racism]], lack of HPD over watch and the reoccurring absence of state and federal investigations. Torres' murder lead to a locally produced, 30-40 minute [[documentary]] entitled ''The Case of Joe Campos Torres'' revealing the murderous event and the repeated history of [[police misconduct]] in Houston. The year following his death, a poetic song by [[vocalist]] and [[activist]] [[Gil Scott-Heron]], titled "Poem for José Campos Torres" was created reflecting the struggles of racism and police criminal actions. ==Background== Torres was born in a Houston [[barrio]] and was raised within [[poverty]]. Unfortunately, he only achieved an eighth-grade education level. A side effect of the poverty, he experienced, led to his constant struggle with his social demeanor.{{cite news|last1=Nolan|first1=Joe|last2=Reyes|first2=Raul|title=Interactive: Joe Campos Torres {{!}} Torres Friends say he had his dreams—and his drawbacks|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/local/torres|accessdate=25 December 2017|work=Houston Chronicle|issue=Volume 76 No. 212|publisher=[[Hearst Newspapers, LLC.]]|date=15 May 1977|page=1|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Katz|first1=Donald|title=The Valley of the Fallen and Other Places|date=2001|publisher=AtRandom.com|location=New York|isbn=0679647228|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Valley_of_the_Fallen.html?id=4jSxrRq_NlcC|accessdate=25 December 2017|language=en|chapter=The "Misdemeanor Murder" of Joe Campos Torres}} According to family and friends, his dream was to run and own a [[karate]] school. He wanted to open the school near his East End Houston neighborhood, allowing him to teach young ones the art of self-defense. To pursue his dream, he realized that he needed a [[General Education Diploma]] (GED), a driver's license and a job as a [[Overhead cable|lineman]] with a telephone company.{{cite news|title=Abilene Reporter-News from Abilene, Texas {{!}} Murder Charges Filed Against Police Officer|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/47645141/|accessdate=25 December 2017|work=United Press (UP)|publisher=Newspapers.com|date=12 May 1977|location=Houston (UP)|page=45|language=en}} Richard Vargas, Torres' longtime friend, said that when Torres was 23 he was still lost emotionally and was fighting a sporadic problem with alcohol. Torres would occasionally become very [[alcohol intoxication|intoxicated]]; friends and family say this would trigger his aggression, in wanting to fight. Torres' younger brothers, Gilbert, 20 and Ray, 16 acknowledged that Torres had an occasional problem with alcohol abuse. "Alcohol really got to him sometimes." Vargas said, "Sometimes when he drank a lot he wanted to fight . . . I didn't like to be around Joe when he was drinking. When he got drunk, he'd start practicing his karate. He'd yell and kick and punch at the air." When Torres was a teenager he got into a lot of fights, but had confided with Vargas and told him he knew the fighting would not get him anywhere.{{cite news|last1=Nolan|first1=Joe|last2=Reyes|first2=Raul|title=Interactive: Joe Campos Torres {{!}} Torres Friends say he had his dreams—and his drawbacks|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/local/torres|accessdate=25 December 2017|work=Houston Chronicle|issue=Volume 76 No. 212|publisher=[[Hearst Newspapers, LLC.]]|date=15 May 1977|page=12|language=en}} Torres' father, José Luna Torres Jr., 46, said his son spent two years in the [[United States Army]] (U.S. Army). During his [[Military service|military service]], he was accepted and undergoing [[United States Army Rangers|Army Ranger]] training at [[Fort Bragg]] [[North Carolina]]. While in ranger training, he was separated from the service in September 1976, under a '[[Military discharge#Types of discharge|general discharge]].' It is reported his abuse of alcohol and anger outbursts are what ultimately led to his early release from the U.S. Army. His brother Gilbert said, "Before the service, Joe was bum and a [[Vagrancy (people)|drifter]], but after he got out he really cut down on the drinking . . . The normal Joe was different from the drunk Joe." He said, "The drunk Joe got rowdy easy and he [take] things the wrong way sometimes."{{cite book|last1=Salinas|first1=Lupe S.|title=U.S. Latinos and Criminal Injustice|date=1 July 2015|publisher=Michigan State University Press|isbn=9781628952353|page=236|url=https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/us-latinos-and-criminal-injustice-lupe-s-salinas/1121923130?ean=9781628952353|accessdate=25 December 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Wilson|first1=Steven Harmon|title=The Rise of Judicial Management in the U.S. District Court, Southern District of Texas, 1955-2000|date=2002|publisher=University of Georgia Press|location=Athens, Ga.|isbn=9780820327280|page=247|chapter=Criminal Justice in the 1970s}}{{cite journal|last1=Curtis|first1=Tom|title=Texas Monthly {{!}} Support Your Local Police (or else)|date=September 1977|volume= 5|issue= 9|page=85|url=https://books.google.sc/books?id=JiwEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA83&vq=campos%20torres&pg=PA85#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=25 December 2017|publisher=Emmis Communications|language=en|issn=0148-7736}} Just two weeks before his death, Torres found employment as a glass contractor earning $2.75 an hour. Vargas said, Torres had difficulty staying employed since his discharge from the U.S. Army. He said Torres resented his restriction to tedious, low paying jobs due to his low education level and nominal military skills. Even though Torres had received, while in the military, training as a telecommunication's lineman not having his GED and a driver's license were barriers to employment with a potential telecommunications provider. Vargas said, Torres' true passions were physical fitness and the art of karate. After his return from the U.S. Army he was working to receive a black belt (expert) rating in karate. In addition to his progress in karate, he also under went weight training and jogged, frequently attaching weights to his feet.{{cite book|last1=Mendoza|first1=Lydia|last2=Nicolopulos|first2=James|last3=Strachwitz|first3=Chris|title=Lydia Mendoza a Family Autobiography|date=1993|publisher=Arte Público|location=Houston, Tex.|isbn=9781558850668|page=353|url=https://books.google.tt/books/about/Lydia_Mendoza.html?hl=pt-BR&id=ll1aAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=25 December 2017|language=spanish}} ==Incident== Torres had been arrested for disorderly conduct at a bar in Houston's predominantly Hispanic East End neighborhood. The six police officers who responded took Torres to a spot called "The Hole" next to the Buffalo Bayou and beat him. The officers then took Torres to the city jail, who refused to process him due to his injuries. They were ordered to take him to [[Ben Taub Hospital]], but instead of doing so, the officers brought him back to the banks of Buffalo Bayou and pushed him into the water. Torres's body was found two days later.{{cite news | title = Nation: End of the Rope | date = April 17, 1978 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,916056-1,00.html | work = Time | accessdate = 2011-02-23}} ==Trials== Officers Terry W. Denson and Steven Orlando were tried on state murder charges.{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2014_00077|title=Grand Jury Investigation into the Death of José Campos Torres (1977)|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1977|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} They were convicted of negligent homicide and received one year of probation and a $1 fine.{{cite news | first = Jack | last = Williams | title = Echos of Moody Park: 30 years later | date = May 8, 2008 | url = http://app1.kuhf.org/houston_public_radio-news-series-moody_park.php | publisher = KUHF-FM | accessdate = 2011-02-23}} Denson, Orlando and fired officer Joseph Janish were later convicted of federal civil rights violations in 1978, and served nine months in prison. ==Moody Park Riot== {{Infobox civil conflict | title = 1978 Moody Park Riot | partof = | image = Moody Park Riot.svg | caption = [[Moody Park]]; Houston, Texas | date = {{start and end dates|1978|05|07|1978|05|08}} | place = Moody Park; Houston, Texas, U.S. | coordinates = {{coord |29.79231 |-95.36425 |display=inline}} | causes = Reaction to light sentencing of police officers in the murder of Joe Campos Torres | goals = • Civil rights • Ending police brutality • Ending police racism | methods = • Arson • Assault • Looting • Rioting • Shooting • Property damage | status = | result = | side1 = Houston's Hispanic community | side2 = Law enforcement | side3 = News team (bystanders) | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = approximately 1,500 | howmany2 = Unknown | howmany3 = Unknown | casualties1 = 8 | casualties2 = 5 | casualties3 = 2 | fatalities = 0 | injuries = 15 | arrests = 28 | detentions = | charged = 4 | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = "Free The Moody Park 3" legal fund started | sidebox = }} On the one year anniversary of José Campos Torres' murder a riot was started at [[Moody Park]] located in Houston's [[Near Northside, Houston|Near Northside]] neighborhood.{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2017_03709|title=Moody Park Riot (1978)|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1978|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} The riot broke out on the evening of Saturday, May 7, 1978 at approximately 7:30 pm, once a {{nowrap|[[Cinco de Mayo]]}} fiesta event ended at the park. Between five and six thousand people attended the celebration.{{cite news|title=Houston history: An ugly Cinco de Mayo celebration|url=http://abc13.com/news/houston-history-an-ugly-cinco-de-mayo-celebration/1326991/|accessdate=10 December 2017|work=ABC13 Houston|agency=KTRK-TV Houston|publisher=ABC Inc.|date=6 May 2016|location=HOUSTON (KTRK)}} {{Quote|width=100%|1=It was the greatest miscarriage of public trust by police officers in my 27 years of wearing a badge.|2=Harry Robinson|3=Former Houston Police Chief|4=Houston History Magazine{{cite journal|last1=Block|first1=Robinson|title=Moody Park: From the Riots to the Future for the Northside Community|journal=Houston History Magazine|date=2 January 2012|volume=9|issue=3|pages=20–22|url=http://houstonhistorymagazine.org/2012/01/volume-9-number-3/|accessdate=10 December 2017|publisher=Houston History Magazine|language=en}}}} Police arrived at the park in response to a call for an incident of disorderly conduct. It remains unclear on how the riot started. Some reports reflect that the officers were making a few arrests and this is when people in the event began yelling, "No you are not taking them" and "You'll kill them the way you killed José Campos Torres". The crowd's initial yelling immediately lead people to begin chanting in unison "Justice for Joe Torres" "Viva Joe Torres" and "A [[Chicano|Chicano's]] life is worth more than a dollar!" The crowd then began throwing bottles and rocks at the officers.{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Jack|title=Moody Park Part 2- The Riot {{!}} Houston Public Media|url=https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2008/05/07/10303/moody-park-part-2-the-riot/|accessdate=10 December 2017|work=Houston Public Media|publisher=University of Houston|date=7 May 2008|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Márquez|first1=John D.|title=Black-Brown Solidarity: Racial Politics in the New Gulf South|date=2014|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=9780292753891|page=125|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=02fKAgAAQBAJ&dq=travis+morales+moody+park&source=gbs_navlinks_s|language=en|chapter=Neoliberalism and Its Aftermath|quote=…all while chanting slogans like "Viva Joe Torres!" "Justice for Joe Torres!" and "A Chicano's life is worth more than a dollar!"}} The Fulton Village shopping center's stores at 2900 Fulton street, were [[looting|looted]] and set on fire. Abe Weiner, an owner of a department store in the shopping center, said it took the fire department over an hour to respond to his emergency [[9-1-1]] call for help. Three large buildings and two smaller ones in the shopping center were looted and stripped by fires. The rioting escalated to over a {{nowrap|ten-block}} area adjacent to Moody Park. A total of six stores and one gasoline station were set on fire.{{cite news|last1=Boyd|first1=John|title=Remembering Joe Campos Torres and Houston's Moody Park riots|url=http://www.chron.com/houston/slideshow/Remembering-Joe-Campos-Torres-and-Houston-s-Moody-108489/photo-6757436.php|accessdate=10 December 2017|work=Houston Chronicle|date=April 28, 2015|language=en|quote=Image 9 of 37 - Caption}} Officers were promptly deployed in [[Riot control#Equipment|riot gear]] to try and control the gathering of approximately 1,500 people according to police (other estimates reflect 150-300) who took part in the riot.{{cite book|last1=León|first1=Arnoldo De|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LFld7B52sSwC&pg=PA211&dq=Joe+Campos+Torres+fighting&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjw6d7j3J3YAhVDjVQKHYsbB_0Q6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=Joe%20Campos%20Torres%20fighting&f=false|title=Ethnicity in the Sunbelt : Mexican Americans in Houston|date=2001|publisher=Texas A & M University Press|location=College Station|isbn=9781585441495|page=211|edition=1st Texas A & M University Press|accessdate=22 December 2017|language=English-USA|chapter=XI Moderation and Inclusions, 1975 -1980s|quote=The mob of about 1,500 according to police (other estimates say 150-300) ...}} Some rioters had flipped cars over and set them on fire, fourteen of the eighteen smashed and burned cars were police cars. The property damage of businesses and police vehicles reached $500,000. At least 28 people were taken into [[Detention (imprisonment)|custody]] after the violence started in the predominantly Mexican-American neighborhood. The incident and all the fires were finally under control at 3:00 am.{{cite news|last1=Cory|first1=Bruce|title=2 Who Incited '78 Houston Riot Fined, Put on 5-Year Probation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1979/05/15/2-who-incited-78-houston-riot-fined-put-on-5-year-probation/364065fc-ef9a-49d4-b397-9e4281c9794b/|accessdate=10 December 2017|work=Washington Post|date=15 May 1979|language=en}} Houston police officer Tommy A. Britt suffered a broken leg when hit by a car while trying to close off one of the streets involved in the riot. The driver Rogelio Castillo did not pull over, but was apprehended a few blocks away from the incident.KPRC-TV The first news reporters to arrive at the scene were KPRC-TV reporter Jack Cato, and reporter/photographer Phil Archer. Both were beaten and stabbed.{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2017_03712|title=KPRC Newsmen Injured During Moody Park Riot (1978)|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1978|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} Cato suffered a punctured lung from a stab wound in the lower back. Archer was hit in the face with a brick and then stabbed in the left hip while lying unconscious on the pavement. Rioters attempted to smash the camera he was carrying. It was later recovered, badly damaged. Cato managed to bring out the video shot during the attack which shows some of the rioters surrounding a burning Houston Fire Department ambulance supervisor's car.KPRC-TV The riot's violence left a total of five police officers, two news personnel and eight rioters injured and hospitalized. None of the fifteen hospitalized people died due to their injuries.{{cite AV media |people= |date=22 October 2017 |title=Moody Park Riots ABC13 Coverage |medium=Television production |language= English |url= http://player.mashpedia.com/player.php?ref=mashpedia&q=TC1bTwVupqE |access-date=9 December 2017 |format= |time=11:55 |location=Houston, TX |orig-year=1978 |publisher=ABC 13 |via=Mashpedia |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= Police are talking with the District Attorney on what charges need to be filed in connection with the disturbance. Charges have already been filed against Rogelio Castillo in connection with the incident, in which the police officer was struck by the car. |ref= |veditors= ((ABC Inc., KTRK-TV Houston))}}{{cite web|author1=Jo Ann Zuiga|author2=S.K. Bardwell|title=10/19/98 Houston Chronicle Article on Pedro Oregon Navarro Shooting|url=http://www.lulac.net/advocacy/issues/rights/hc10-19.html|website=www.lulac.net|publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=10 December 2017|language=en|date=19 October 1998|quote=... lack of punishment prompted the Moody Park riot, which sent 15 people to the hospital.}} ==Popular culture== ===Books=== Author Dwight Watson dedicated the chapter "The Storm Clouds of Change: The Death of José Campos Torres and the Emergence of Triracial Politics in Houston" in the book ''Race and the Houston Police Department, 1930–1990 A Change Did Come''. The chapter covers the impact of Torres' murder on society and changes in Houston's policing policies.{{cite web |last1=Macías |first1=Francisco |title=Remembering José "Joe" Campos Torres's Last Cinco de Mayo |url=https://blogs.loc.gov/law/2015/05/jose-campos-torress/|publisher=Library of Congress |date=May 5, 2015 |accessdate=November 29, 2017}}{{cite book|last1=Watson|first1=Dwight|title=Race and the Houston police department, 1930-1990 : a change did come|date=2005|publisher=Texas A & M University Press|location=College Station, Texas|isbn=9781585444373|edition=1st|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3399814-race-and-the-houston-police-department-1930-1990|accessdate=1 December 2017}} {{Quote | text = It brought people who were very conservative and very quiet to become very vocal and very political and people began to hold the police accountable.{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Jack |title=Moody Park- The Aftermath|url=http://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2008/05/08/10314/moody-park-the-aftermath/ |publisher=Houston Public Media |date = May 8, 2008 |accessdate=November 29, 2017}} | author = Dwight Watson | title = "Moody Park–The Aftermath", interview by Houston Public Media | publisher = Houston Public Media }} ===Music=== ====Poem for José Campos Torres==== {{external media | headerimage = | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pYt2K6vacv0&feature=youtu.be "Poem for José Campos Torres"
] | caption = [https://genius.com/Gil-scott-heron-jose-campos-torres-lyricsLyrics of song] | float = right | width = 284px | accessdate = 2017-11-29 }} Vocalist and activist [[Gil Scott-Heron]], known as the "Godfather of Rap" and for his sociology charged spoken word performances in the '70s. Scott-Heron's best-known recording is the 1971 released "The Revolution Will Not be Televised", this artwork characterizes unashamed [[consumerism]].{{cite news|last1=Contreras|first1=Felix|title=Gil Scott-Heron Dies: Rhymes For La Revolución|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/altlatino/2011/05/29/136742644/gil-scott-heron-dies-rhymes-for-la-revoluci-n |publisher=NPR |date=May 8, 2011 |accessdate=November 29, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Stephen|title=The legendary godfather of rap returns|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/newsnight/8362518.stm|accessdate=16 December 2017|date=16 November 2009}} Scott-Heron's artistry based on self-fortitude and resentment of racism spanned across racial cultures and was popular among both African-Americans and Latinos. In 1978, the year following Torres' murder, he targeted community awareness of the murder and created a poetic song focusing on America's systemic abuse of [[Asian-Americans]], African-Americans and Hispanics in the heartfelt "Poem for José Campos Torres."{{cite web|title=Antiwar Songs (AWS) - José Campos Torres|url=https://www.antiwarsongs.org/canzone.php?id=39853&lang=en|publisher=Antiwarsongs |accessdate=November 29, 2017}} The song was released as track 4 of the album titled; ''[[The Mind of Gil Scott-Heron]].''{{cite web|title=Mind of Gil Scott-Heron|url=https://www.amazon.com/Mind-Gil-Scott-Heron/dp/B000056VIS|website=amazon.com|publisher=Tvt|accessdate=16 December 2017|date=30 January 2001}} Scott-Heron saw Torres as a brother and made his familial tie to Torres in the lyrics, here is a quote from the song:{{cite web|title=Gil Scott-Heron – Jose Campos Torres Lyrics {{!}} Genius Lyrics|url=https://genius.com/Gil-scott-heron-jose-campos-torres-lyrics|accessdate=16 December 2017|language=en|quote=José Campos Torres {{!}} Produced by Gil Scott-Heron {{!}} Album The Mind of Gil Scott Heron}} {{poemquote | 1 = ♪ But brother Torres, common ancient bloodline brother Torres is dead ♪ ♪ I had said I wasn't going to write no more poems like this ♪ ♪ I had said I wasn't going to write no more words down ♪ ♪ About people kicking us when we're down ♪ ♪ About racist dogs that attack us and drive us down, drag us down and beat us down ♪ ♪ But the dogs are in the street ♪ | char = | sign = Gil Scott-Heron | source = Album: ''The Mind of Gil Scott-Heron'' | title = "Poem for José Campos Torres" | style = }} ====El Ballad De José Campos Torres==== {{External media | audio1 = [https://archive.org/details/AccordionNoirJan18Wed "El Ballad De José Campos Torres"
(0:53 - 5:29)] | float = right | width = 284px | accessdate = 2018-01-01 }} Charanga Cakewalk is the stage name for Michael Ramos, a self-described Latino Chicano Mexican who is also a citizen of the world. Ramos, from Austin, TX, is an instrumental artist who passes a distinguishing sound of Latino music onto the next generation of artistry. Ramos has played numerous instruments in studios and on-tours for [[John Mellencamp]], [[Patty Griffin]], [[Los Lonely Boys]], [[Paul Simon]] and multiple notable artist.{{cite web|title=Chicano Zen by Charanga Cakewalk on Apple Music|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/chicano-zen/141568995|website=itunes.apple.com|publisher=Apple Inc.|accessdate=2 January 2018|language=en-us|date=28 March 2006}}{{cite journal|editor1-last=Taylor|editor1-first=Chuck|title=Reviews - Singles|journal=Billboard|date=1 April 2006|volume=118|issue=13|page=46|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DxYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=Ballad+de+Jose+Campos+Torres&source=bl&ots=Tp62E2nJ3z&sig=C9DP896v6slQk9ZnefxW6uGrfI4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAl8PukI3YAhUO0WMKHSVuDlw4FBDoAQgnMAA#v=onepage&q=Ballad%20de%20Jose%20Campos%20Torres&f=false|accessdate=2 January 2018|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|location=New York, NY|language=en|issn=0006-2510}} His artwork is self-styled as Cumbia-Tronic that soars between absorbed Electronic Dance and cultivated genres of [[Cumbia]], [[Ranchera]], Folklorica, and [[Garage Rock]].{{cite news|last1=Acosta|first1=Belinda|title=Charanga Cakewalk {{!}} Record Review|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2006-05-12/364680/|accessdate=2 January 2018|agency=Austin Chronicle|publisher=Austin Chronicle Corp|date=12 May 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005202826/https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2006-05-12/364680/|archivedate=5 October 2015|language=english}}{{cite web|title=Summer Sessions 2007 (Visit the Getty)|url=https://www.getty.edu/visit/events/summer_sessions_2007.html|website=www.getty.edu|publisher=J. Paul Getty Trust|accessdate=2 January 2018|location=Los Angeles, CA.|language=en|date=2007|quote=Prior to forming his "cumbia-tronic" project, Ramos played keyboards and accordion for artists like John Mellencamp, Patty Griffin, Paul Simon, and the Rembrandts.}} In March 2006, Charanga Cakewalk released the album ''Chicano Zen''. The album has multiple instrumental songs, track 11 the closing song is the instrumental titled: "El Ballad de José Campos Torres", with a synth, accordion and piano drift inspired by the life of Torres:{{cite web|title=Charanga Cakewalk - Chicano Zen|url=https://www.discogs.com/Charanga-Cakewalk-Chicano-Zen/release/5634497|website=Discogs|accessdate=2 January 2018|language=en|date=2006|quote=Track:11, Title: El Ballad De Jose Campos Torres, Duration: 4:50}}{{cite web|title=El Ballad de Jose Campos Torres|url=https://us.napster.com/artist/charanga-cakewalk/album/chicano-zen/track/el-ballad-de-jose-campos-torres|website=napster.com|accessdate=2 January 2018|date=28 March 2006}} {{Quote | text = So many people think of what happened to José Campos Torres, but I got [to] thinking about him as a person, who he was, what he felt, how he lived.{{cite news|last1=Marsh|first1=Dave|title=The Zen of Revolution: Michael Ramos' Charanga Cakewalk|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2006-08-18/395778/|accessdate=2 January 2018|publisher=Austin Chronicle Corp.|date=18 August 2006|language=en}} | author = Michael Ramos | title = The Zen of Revolution | publisher = Austin Chronicle }} ====Moody Park Riot (José Campos Torres)==== {{External media | audio1 = [https://soundcloud.com/nunorecords/moody-park-riot-jose-campos "Moody Park Riot (José Campos Torres)"] | float = right | width = 284px | accessdate = 2017-11-29 }} In 2014 Nuño Records published, via SoundCloud, the song "Moody Park Riot (José Campos Torres)" written by Juan Nuño performed by Jesse James at Houston, TX. The lyrics depict Torres' beating and drowning along with events tied to the 1978 Moody Park Riot.{{cite web|title=Moody Park Riot (Jose Campos Torres) {{!}} written by Juan Nuno performed by Jesse James at Houston|url=https://soundcloud.com/nunorecords/moody-park-riot-jose-campos|website=soundcloud.com|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en}} ===Television=== ====Interview with Janie Torres==== {{external media | headerimage = | video1 = [https://vimeo.com/215862395 "Joe Campos Torres, 40 years ago"] | caption = | float = right | width = 284px | accessdate = 2018-02-12 }} Art Browning hosted a television interview with Torres' little sister Janie Torres. The episode, produced by Green Watch Television (GWTV), is titled: "Joe Campos Torres, 40 years ago", first aired: Wednesday, April 26, 2017, duration: 24 min. When Browning asked about her thoughts on the establishment of [[Black Lives Matter]] she replied: {{Quote |text = "Wow I was amazed, it was something that was so well, well over due for the people" she continued, "Justice is equal, justice is what we deserve that's all we want, we don't want anymore any less." | author = Janie Torres | title = "Joe Campos Torres, 40 years ago" (interview) | publisher = GWTV }} At the closing of the interview, Janie Torres, who was only a {{nowrap|10-year-old}} when her brother's life was taken, announced plans for an annual [[solidarity]] walk in memory of her brother. The walk is targeted across all generations with the focus on awareness of police racism across the nation. The second annual walk and rally occurred on May 6, 2017 in Houston, Texas. Janie plans on continuing to hold the walks annually, to be held on the yearly anniversaries of her brother's murder. For social awareness she has posted the walk on a [[Facebook]] homepage; [https://www.facebook.com/solidaritywalkhouston/ "Joe Campos Torres Solidarity Walk For Past & Future Generations"].{{cite news|last1=Browning|first1=Art|title=Joe Campos Torres, 40 years ago (GWTV 2017-04-26) Greenwatch TV|url=https://vimeo.com/channels/greenwatch/215862395|accessdate=30 November 2017|publisher=Green Watch Television (GWTV)|date=3 May 2017|location=Houston, TX}} ===Films=== ====The Case of Joe Campos Torres==== The documentary ''The Case of Joe Campos Torres'' recounts the calendar of events and ensuing community-protest assemblies, community/police department discussions, along with the legal actions taken by the Torres family against the Houston Police Department and the City of Houston.{{cite web|title=May 8: The Case of Joe Campos Torres (Film)|url=https://doscentavos.net/2014/05/02/may-8-the-case-of-joe-campos-torres-film/|website=doscentavos.net|accessdate=30 November 2017|date=2 May 2014}}{{cite web|title=Shared Histories Film Screening and Panel Discussion: The Case of Joe Campos Torres|url=http://www.artshound.com/event/shared-histories-film-screening-and-panel-discussion-the-case-of-joe-campos-torres/|website=Arts Hound|accessdate=30 November 2017}} Filmed around Houston, the documentary records the Latino communities reaction to what they witnessed as an act of racial injustice against their population. The documentary, approximately 30 – 40 minutes in length, replays raw [[footage]] taken from local news station's archives. The footage is used as a reminder to viewers that before video cameras were able to bring police misconduct to light, the family of Torres had to rely on community support to help them find justice.{{cite news|last1=Ruiz|first1=Raymond|title="The Case of Joe Campos Torres" debuts to a packed house - The Venture|url=https://www.theventureonline.com/2011/07/the-case-of-joe-campos-torres-debuts-to-a-packed-house/|accessdate=30 November 2017|work=The Venture|date=28 July 2011}} The film was produced in 1977 by Tony Bruni and Houston's [[KPRC-TV]], Channel 2. Carlos Calbillo both wrote and edited the film and it was reported by [[John Quiñones]], who is now with [[ABC News]] and hosts the series "[[What Would You Do? (ABC News series)|What Would You Do?]]". ==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Death of Freddie Gray]] * [[Death of John Hernandez]] * [[Chad Holley]] * [[Dallas Police Department#Killing of Santos Rodriguez|''Killing of Santos Rodriguez'']] * [[Wilmington Ten]] * [[List of killings by law enforcement officers in the United States|List of killings by law enforcement officers in the U.S.]] * [[Police brutality in the United States]] * [[Houston riot of 1917]] }} {{-}} {{Subject bar |portal1=Biography |portal2=Criminal justice |portal3=Discrimination |portal4=Hispanic and Latino Americans |portal5=Houston |portal6=Human rights |portal7=Law enforcement |portal8=Poetry}} {{-}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.facebook.com/solidaritywalkhouston/ Joe Campos Torres Solidarity Walk For Past & Future Generations] Facebook page {{Authority control}} {{Houston Police Department}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Torres, Joe Campos}} [[Category:Police misconduct in the United States]] [[Category:Race riots in the United States]] [[Category:Victims of police brutality]] [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:1977 crimes]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:1977 in Texas]] [[Category:1977 events in the United States]] [[Category:1977 murders in the United States]] [[Category:American manslaughter victims]] [[Category:American murder victims]] [[Category:American people of Mexican descent]] [[Category:Civil rights protests in the United States]] [[Category:Crimes in Houston]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths in police custody in the United States]] [[Category:History of Houston]] [[Category:History of racism in the United States]] [[Category:Houston Police Department]] [[Category:Houston Police Department officers]] [[Category:Law enforcement in Texas]] [[Category:Manslaughter victims]] [[Category:May 1977 events]] [[Category:Media-related controversies in the United States]] [[Category:Mexican-American culture in Houston]] [[Category:Murder in Texas]] [[Category:Murdered Mexican Americans]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:People murdered in Texas]] [[Category:Police brutality in the United States]] [[Category:Police misconduct]] [[Category:Protests in the United States]] [[Category:Race and crime in the United States]] [[Category:Racially motivated violence against Hispanic and Latino Americans]] [[Category:Racially motivated violence in the United States]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Texas]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Elephant Hotel 2007.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Statue of Old Bet in front of the [[Elephant Hotel]], in [[Somers, New York]].]] [[File:OldBetSlayingMarker.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Marker of site in [[Alfred, ME]] where Old Bet was killed.]] '''Old Bet''' (died July 24, 1816) was the first circus elephant and the second elephant brought to the United States.<ref name=top>{{cite news |first= Roberta|last= Hershenson|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Under the Big Top |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03E2DD123BF93BA35751C1A9649C8B63 |quote=Old Bet, called ''the second elephant in America'' by the Somers Historical Society, was also one of the most important elephants in America. The [[Elephant Hotel]] in Somers was built in 1825 to honor her, and her owner, [[Hachaliah Bailey]] of Somers, and is now in its third century of circus fame. Old Bet was part of the new tradition of menageries -- elephants, tigers, giraffes, rhinos and other exotic animals imported from abroad -- that traveled the countryside with circuses beginning about 1804. Now an exhibition and a theatrical production recall those early circus days. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=December 8, 2002 |accessdate=2007-07-21 }}</ref> There are reports of an elephant brought to the United States in 1796, but it is not known for certain that this was the elephant that was later named Old Bet.<ref name=heritage>{{cite web |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1974/3/1974_3_102.shtml |title=Setting The Record Straight On Old Bet. |accessdate=2008-03-21 |quote=It is not an established fact that Old Bet was the first elephant to arrive in America, and quite possibly she was second. An April, 1796, publication, ''Greenleaf’s New York'', mentions an elephant journeying to our shores aboard the ship ''America''. A few days later an elephant was exhibited around Beaver Street and Broadway, according to an advertisement in The Argus, April 23, 1796. This area was the location of the [[Bull's Head Tavern]], a place frequented by ships’ captains, drovers, and a variety of businessmen. Hachaliah Bailey of Somers, New York, regularly stayed at the Bull’s Head when he took his cattle to the abattoir, which was located nearby. The newspaper reports that the first elephant was sold to a 'Mister Owen.' Unfortunately, they gave no other information about the man, nor did they tell what he did with the elephant he bought, but Hachaliah Bailey’s business partner and brother-in-law was named Owen. |publisher=''[[American Heritage (magazine)|American Heritage]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315072915/http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1974/3/1974_3_102.shtml |archivedate=March 15, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="america">{{cite book |url=http://um.bookprep.com/read/mdp.39015027042459 |title=An Account of the Private Armed Ship "America" of Salem |work=um.bookprep.com |last=Crowninshield |first=Bowdoin Bradlee |publisher=The Essex Institute Historical Collection |volume=XXXVII |page=1 |year=1901 |accessdate=March 3, 2013 }}</ref>
==Biography== The first elephant brought to the United States was in 1796, aboard the ''[[Private Armed Ship America|America]]'' which set sail from [[Calcutta, India|Calcutta]] for New York on December 3, 1795.<ref name="Goodwin(1951)">{{cite web|last=Goodwin|first=George G.|title=The Crowninshield Elephant : The surprising story of Old Bet, the first elephant ever to be brought to America|url=http://www.naturalhistorymag.com/htmlsite/master.html?http://www.naturalhistorymag.com/htmlsite/editors_pick/1951_10_pick.html|work=Pick from the Past|publisher=''[[Natural History (magazine)|Natural History]]''|accessdate=29 January 2013|date=October 1951}}</ref> However, it is not certain that this was Old Bet.<ref name=heritage/> The first references to Old Bet start in 1804 in [[Boston]] as part of a [[menagerie]].<ref name=top/> In 1808, while residing in [[Somers, New York]], [[Hachaliah Bailey]] purchased the menagerie elephant for $1,000 and named it "Old Bet".<ref name=roadside>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/pet/oldbet.html |title=Old Bet |accessdate=2010-01-08 |quote= |publisher=[[RoadsideAmerica.com]] }}</ref><ref name=Times>{{cite news|last=Wiegold|first=Marilyn|date=May 15, 1977|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/05/15/archives/the-beast-that-put-somers-on-the-map.html?mcubz=0&_r=0|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170613181833/http://www.nytimes.com/1977/05/15/archives/the-beast-that-put-somers-on-the-map.html?mcubz=0&_r=0|archivedate=June 13, 2017|accessdate=June 13, 2017|title=The Beast That Put Somers on the Map|work=Archives|publisher=[[The New York Times]]}}.</ref>
On July 24, 1816, Old Bet was killed while on tour near [[Alfred, Maine]] by local farmer Daniel Davis who shot her, and was later convicted of the crime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faithfulreaders.com/2012/06/03/elephants/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161108204136/https://faithfulreaders.com/2012/06/03/elephants/|archivedate=November 8, 2016|date=June 3, 2012|last=Winship|first=Kihm|title=Elephants|work=Faithful Readers: The writing of Kihm Winship}}</ref> While many people believe that the farmer thought it was sinful for people to pay to see an animal, another suspected reason is jealousy.<ref name=heritage/><ref name=roadside/>
==Legacy== In 1821, the [[Barnum's American Museum]] in New York announced that they had bought the hide and bones of Old Bet and would mount the remains at the museum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historybuff.com/library/refelephant.html |title=The Elephant Comes to America |accessdate=2010-01-08 |quote=In 1821, the American Museum in New York announced that they had bought Old Bet and she would now be on permanent display at the museum. |publisher=HistoryBuff.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212035825/http://www.historybuff.com/library/refelephant.html |archivedate=2010-02-12 |df= }}</ref> The elephant was memorialized in 1825 with a statue and the [[Elephant Hotel]] in Somers, New York.<ref name=top/><ref name=heritage/><ref name=roadside/> In 1922 the elephant [[John L. Sullivan (elephant)|John L. Sullivan]] walked 53 miles to lay a wreath for the memory of Old Bet at her memorial statue.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Namesake of 'John L.' Will Lay Wreath on Grave of Pioneer Sister Performer |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B01E6D91E3CE533A2575AC0A9629C946395D6CF |quote=An old, old elephant will start out this afternoon from Madison Square Garden on a pilgrimage to the grave of the first elephant that ever came to the United States. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=April 9, 1922 |accessdate=2010-01-08 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Town Heaps Honors on Old Bet's Grave. But Pap Fellowes and His Cornet Inject a Little Discord in Memorial to an Elephant. But the Youngsters All Enjoy It and Feed Peanuts to Old John, Who Lays Wreath on Monument |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CE3DE1739EF3ABC4C52DFB2668389639EDE |quote=The memorial services for Old Bet in Somers, N.Y., yesterday, solemn except for the part which old Pap Fellowes and the cornet played, were all that anybody, even Old Bet herself, might have wished. But it is true that Pap sort of gummed things up. Pap did something to the cornet out behind ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=April 14, 1922 |accessdate=2010-01-08 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite web|last1=Collins|first1=Kate Irish|title=Elephant named Old Bet not forgotten|url=http://www.keepmecurrent.com/reporter/news/elephant-named-old-bet-not-forgotten/article_022aedb0-d3e3-11e0-8e6a-001cc4c002e0.html?mode=jqm|website=Keep ME Current|publisher=Current Publishing; Waterboro Reporter|accessdate=31 July 2014|date=31 Aug 2011}} *{{cite web|title=Old Bet's Miserable Summer|url=http://www.oldberwick.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=446:nov-17-2011-old-bets-miserable-summer&catid=36:past-programs&Itemid=55|publisher=Old Berwick Historical Society|accessdate=31 July 2014|date=17 Nov 2011}}
==External links== *[http://www.travelchannel.com/video/first-circus-elephant "First Circus Elephant" (video)] — Old Bet, featured on a segment of ''[[Monumental Mysteries]]'', (originally aired: 25 July 2013 on [[Travel Channel]])
[[Category:1816 animal deaths]] [[Category:Individual elephants]] [[Category:Circus performers]]

revision.text:
{{for|the professional wrestler|Onryo (wrestler)}} [[File:Hokusai Onryo.jpg|thumb|Onryō from the Kinsei-Kaidan-Shimoyonohoshi (近世怪談霜夜星)]] In traditional beliefs of Japan and in literature, '''''onryō''''' ([[wiktionary:怨霊|怨霊]], literally "vengeful spirit", sometimes rendered "wrathful spirit")<ref name="grappard"/> refers to a ghost (''[[yūrei]]'') believed capable of causing harm in the world of the living, harming or killing enemies, or even causing natural disasters to exact [[Revenge|vengeance]] to redress the wrongs it received while alive then takes their spirits from their dying bodies.
The term overlaps somewhat with {{nihongo||御霊|[[goryō]]}}, except that in the cult of the ''goryō'', the acting agent need not necessarily be a wrathful spirit.<ref name="grappard"/>
==Origin== While the origin of ''onryō'' is unclear, belief in their existence can be traced back to the 8th century and was based on the idea that powerful and enraged souls of the dead could influence or harm the living people. The earliest ''onryō'' cult that developed was around [[Prince Nagaya]] who died in 729;<ref name="grappard"/> and the first record of possession by the ''onryō'' spirit affecting the health is found in the chronicle ''[[Shoku Nihongi]]'' (797), which states that "{{nihongo|[[Fujiwara Hirotsugu]]|[[:ja:藤原広嗣|藤原広嗣]]}}'s soul harmed [[Genbō]] to death" (Hirotsugu having died in a failed insurrection, named the "[[Fujiwara no Hirotsugu Rebellion]]", after failing to remove his rival, the priest Genbō, from power).<ref>For a source that identifies Hirotsugu as ''onryō'', see:{{Harvnb|Suzuki|2011|loc=135 (note 2 to Chapter 2)}}</ref><ref>A source that gives Hirotsugu as first example on record of "etiological possession" is {{Harvnb|McCullough|1973|p=97}}</ref>
==Vengeance== Traditionally in Japan, ''onryō'' driven by [[Revenge|vengeance]] were thought capable of causing not only their enemy's death, as in the case of Hirotsugu's vengeful spirit held responsible for killing the priest [[Genbō]],<ref>{{citation|last=McCullough|first=William H.|title=Spirit Possession in the Heian Period|editor-last1=Ōta|editor-first1=Saburo (太田三郎)|editor-last2=Fukuda|editor-first2=Rikutaro (福田陸太郎)|journal=Studies on Japanese Culture (日本文化研究論集)|volume=1|year=1973|page=97|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qLAdAQAAMAAJ}}; (Also printed in ''Nihon Bunka Kenkyū Kokusai Kaigi gijiroku'' (日本文化研究国際会議議事錄) ([https://books.google.com/books?id=RN9YAAAAMAAJ Volume 1, 1973], pp. 350- (p.356)</ref>), but causing natural disasters such as [[earthquake]]s, [[fire]]s, [[storm]]s, [[drought]], [[famine]] and [[Pandemic|pestilence]],<ref name="grappard"/> as in the case of [[Prince Sawara]]'s spirit embittered against his brother, the [[Emperor Kanmu]].<ref name="suzuki">{{cite book|last=Suzuki|first=Yui|title=Medicine Master Buddha: The Iconic Worship of Yakushi in Heian Japan|publisher=BRILL|year=2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dgo7JV9vNCQC&pg=PA29|pages=29–31|isbn=978-9004196018}}</ref> In common parlance, such vengeance exacted by supernatural beings or forces is termed {{nihongo||[[:ja:祟り|祟り]]|tatari}}.<ref name="grappard">{{citation|last=Grappard|first=Allan G.|contribution=Religious practices|editor-last=Hall|editor-first=John Whitney|volume=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eiTWWfoyuyAC&pg=PA560|pages=559–|isbn=978-0521223539|title=The Cambridge History of Japan|year=1988}}</ref>
The [[Emperor Kanmu]] had accused his brother Sawara of plotting (possibly falsely to remove him as rival to the throne), and the latter who was exiled died by fasting. The reason that the Emperor moved the capital to [[Nagaoka-kyō]] thence to [[Kyoto]] was an attempt to avoid the wrath of his brother's spirit, according to a number of scholars.<ref name="suzuki"/> This not succeeding entirely, the emperor tried to lift the curse by appeasing his brother's ghost, by performing Buddhist rites to pay respect, and granting Prince Sawara the posthumous title of emperor.<ref name="suzuki"/>
A well-known example of appeasement of the ''onryō'' spirit is the case of [[Sugawara no Michizane]], who had been politically disgraced and died in exile. Believed to cause the death of his calumniators in quick succession, as well as catastrophes (especially lightning damage), and the court tried to appease the wrathful spirit by restoring Michizane's old rank and position.<ref name="grappard"/> Michizane became deified in the cult of the [[Tenjin (kami)|Tenjin]], with [[Tenman-gū]] shrines erected around him.
===Examples=== Possibly the most famous ''onryō'' is Oiwa, from the ''[[Yotsuya Kaidan]]''. In this story the husband remains unharmed; however, he is the target of the ''onryō''’s vengeance. Oiwa's vengeance on him isn't physical retribution, but rather psychological torment.
Other examples include:
*'''''How a Man's Wife Became a [[Vengeful ghost|Vengeful Ghost]] and How Her Malignity Was Diverted by a Master of Divination''''' :In this tale from the medieval collection, ''[[Konjaku Monogatarishū]]'', an abandoned wife is found dead with a full head of hair intact and the bones still attached. The husband, fearing retribution from her spirit, asks a {{Nihongo|diviner|[[:ja:陰陽師|陰陽師]]|onmyōji}} for aid. The husband must endure while grabbing her hair and riding astride her corpse. She complains of the heavy load and leaves the house to "go looking" (presumably for the husband), but after a day she gives up and returns, after which the diviner is able to complete her exorcism with an incantation.<ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Jones|editor-first=S. W. (translator)|title=Ages ago; thirty-seven tales from the Konjaku monogatari collection|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1959|page=72|format=snippet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nv-wAAAAIAAJ}}</ref><ref>One of the texts cited by Jones: {{citation|editor-last=Haga|editor-first=Yaichi (芳賀矢一)|chapter=卷第廿四/第20: 人妻成悪靈除其害陰陽師語 |work=攷証今昔物語集 (Kōshō konjaku monogatari shū)|volume=3 (下)|year=1921|page=106|url=http://dl.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/945416}}</ref>
*'''''Of a Promise Broken''''' :In this tale from the [[Izumo Province|Izumo]] area recorded by [[Lafcadio Hearn]], a [[samurai]] vows to his dying wife never to remarry. He soon breaks the promise, and the ghost comes to first warn, then murder the young bride, ripping her head off. The watchmen who had been put to sleep chase down the apparition, and with a slash of the sword while reciting [[Buddhist]] prayer, destroys it.<ref>{{citation|last=Hearn|first=Lafcadio|chapter=Of a Promise Broken|publisher=Little, Brown|year=1901|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DGEiAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA15|pages=15–26|title=A Japanese miscellany}}</ref>
==In media== Hisako (久子, "Eternal Child" or "Everlasting Child") from the third entry of the fighting game Killer Instinct, is an onryō who died while defending her village. She still haunts her old village and will take vengeance on anyone who desecrates it's ruins with her naginata. She has pale white skin, long black hair like most Onryo. <ref>https://www.ultra-combo.com/characters/hisako/</ref>
In Fall 2018 the asymetrical horror game, Dead By Daylight released The Spirit DLC. The Spirit is an onryō who returns from the dead after being brutally murdered by her Father.
==Physical appearance== Traditionally,{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} ''onryō'' and other ''[[yūrei]]'' (ghosts) had no particular appearance. However, with the rising of popularity of [[Kabuki]] during the [[Edo period]], a specific [[costume]] was developed.
Highly visual in nature, and with a single actor often assuming various roles within a play, Kabuki developed a system of visual shorthand that allowed the audience to instantly clue in as to which character is on stage, as well as emphasize the emotions and expressions of the actor.
A ghost costume consisted of three main elements: * White burial [[kimono]], {{nihongo||[[:ja:白装束|白装束]]|shiroshōzoku}} or {{nihongo||[[:ja:死に装束|死に装束]]|shinishōzoku}} *Wild, unkempt long black hair *Face make-up consisting of white foundation (''[[oshiroi]]'') coupled with face paintings (''[[kumadori]]'') of {{nihongo|blue shadows|藍隈|aiguma|extra2="[[indigo]] fringe"}}, much like villains are depicted in kabuki make-up artistry.<ref>{{cite book|author=日本博学倶楽部|title=「通」になれる古典芸能を楽しむ本: 落語・歌舞伎から能・狂言まで|publisher=PHP研究所|year=2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpY2LFHGK34C&pg=PT57|page=57|isbn=978-4569665498}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Parker|first=Helen S. E.|title=Progressive Traditions: An Illustrated Study of Plot Repetition In Traditional Japanese Theatre|publisher=BRILL|year=2006|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L3pp4I-eoZIC&pg=PA87|page=87|isbn=978-9004145344}}</ref><ref group="lower-alpha">In addition to blue, {{nihongo|brown shadows|代赭隈|taishaguma|extra2="[[red ochre]] fringe"}} or black [[kumadori]]({{Harvnb|日本博学倶楽部|2005|p=57}})</ref>
==See also== *[[Japanese urban legends]] *[[Ghosts in Vietnamese culture]] *[[Kayako Saeki]] *[[Sadako Yamamura]] *[[S-Ko]] *[[List of ghosts]] *''[[Fatal Frame]]'' (video game) *''[[Muoi: The Legend of a Portrait]]'' (film) *[[Vengeful ghost]]
