revision.comment: Original research; the papers cited are about the specific means by which Lake Bonneville became saline, not the article topic
revision.text:
{{Lead rewrite|reason= Lead does not summarize content.|date=November 2014}}
'''Alexander Tollmann's bolide''', proposed by [[Edith Kristan-Tollmann]] and [[Alexander Tollmann]] in 1994,<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994">Kristan-Tollmann, E. and A. Tollmann, 1994, ''The youngest big impact on Earth deduced from geological and historical evidence''. Terra Nova. v. 6, no. 2, pp. 209–217.</ref> is a hypothesis presented by [[Austria]]n [[geologist]] Alexander Tollmann and [[paleontologist]] Edith Kristan-Tollmann, suggesting that one or several [[bolide]]s ([[asteroid]]s or [[comet]]s) [[impact event|struck the Earth]] at 7640 BCE (±200), with a much smaller one at 3150 BCE (±200). If true, this hypothesis explains early [[Holocene extinction event|Holocene extinctions]] and possibly legends of the [[Deluge (mythology)|Universal Deluge]].<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994"/>
The claimed evidence for the event includes [[stratigraphy|stratigraphic]] studies of [[tektites]],<ref name="Glass1978">Glass, B.P., 1978, ''Australasian Microtektites and the Stratigraphic Age of the Australites'' Bulletin of the Geological Society of America. v. 89, no. 10, pp. 1455–1458.</ref><ref name="Izokh1988">Izokh, E.P., 1988, ''Age-paradox and the Origin of Tektites'' in J. Konta, ed., 2nd international conference on natural glasses'' Abstracts – International Conference on Natural Glasses-Prague, Czechoslovakia, 1988. v. 2, pp. 379–384.</ref><ref name="PrasadOthers1990">Prasad, N.S. and P.S. Rao, 1990, ''Tektites Far and Wide''. Nature. v. 347, no. 6291, pp. 340.</ref> [[dendrochronology]], and [[ice core]]s (from Camp Century, [[Greenland]]) containing [[hydrochloric acid]] and [[sulfuric acid]] (indicating an energetic ocean strike) as well as [[nitric acid]]s (caused by extreme heating of air).
[[Christopher Knight (author)|Christopher Knight]] and [[Robert Lomas]] in their book, ''[[Uriel's Machine]]'', argue that the 7640 BCE evidence is consistent with the dates of formation of a number of extant [[Salt pan (geology)|salt flat]]s and lakes in dry areas of [[North America]] and [[Asia]]. They argue that these lakes are the result remains of multiple-kilometer-high waves that penetrated deeply into continents as the result of oceanic strikes that they proposed occurred.
==Scientific evaluation== [[Quaternary]] geologists, [[paleoclimatologist]]s, and planetary [[geologist]]s specializing in [[meteorite]] and [[comet]] impacts have rejected the Tollmann bolide hypothesis.<ref name="DeutschOthers1993">Deutsch, A., C. Koeberl, J.D. Blum, B.M. French, B.P. Glass, R. Grieve, P. Horn, E.K. Jessberger, G. Kurat, W.U. Reimold, J. Smit, D. Stöffler, and S.R. Taylor, 1994, ''The impact-flood connection: Does it exist?'' Terra Nova. v. 6, pp. 644–650.</ref> They reject this hypothesis because:
# The evidence offered to support the hypothesis can more readily be explained by more mundane and less dramatic geologic processes # Many of the events alleged to be associated with this impact occurred at the wrong time (i.e., many of the events occurred hundreds to thousands of years before or after the hypothesized impacts); and # There is a lack of any credible physical evidence for the cataclysmic environmental devastation and characteristic deposits that kilometer-high [[tsunamis]] would have created had they actually occurred.<ref name="DeutschOthers1993"/>
Much of the evidence used by the Tollmann bolide hypothesis to argue for catastrophic [[Holocene]] impacts can be just as well, in most cases even better, explained by more pedestrian geological processes. For example, the chemical composition of and the presence of [[volcanic ash]] with the specific acidity spikes in the [[Greenland]] [[ice cores]] presents clear evidence that they are [[volcanic eruption|volcanic]], not impact, in origin.<ref name="HammerOthers1980">Hammer, C.U., H.B. Clausen, and W. Dansgaard, 1980, ''Greenland ice sheet evidence of post-glacial volcanism and its climatic impact''. Nature. v. 288, no. 5788, pp. 230–235.</ref><ref name="ZielinskiOthers1996">Zielinski, G.A., P.A. Mayewski, L.D. Meeker, S. Whitlow, and M.S. Twickler, 1996, ''A 110,000 year record of explosive volcanism from the GISP2 (Greenland) ice core''. Quaternary Research. v. 45, no. 2, pp. 109–118.</ref> Also, the largest acidity spikes found in [[Antarctica]] ice cores are far too old, from 17,300 to 17,500 BP, to be associated with any [[Holocene]] impacts.<ref name="HammerOthers1997">Hammer, C.U., H.B. Clausen and C. Langway, Jr., 1997, ''50,000 years of recorded global volcanism''. Climatic Change. v. 35, no. 1, pp. 1–15.</ref> The formation of modern [[salt lake]]s and [[Salt pan (geology)|salt flat]]s is readily explained by the concentration of salts and other [[evaporite]] minerals by the [[evaporation]] of water from stream-fed lakes lacking external outlets, called [[endorheic|"endorheic lakes"]], in arid climates. The composition of the salts and other evaporate minerals found in these lakes is consistent with their precipitation from dissolved material continually carried into the lakes by rivers and streams and subsequent concentration by evaporation instead of evaporation of sea water.<ref name="EugesterOthers1980">Eugster, H.P., 1980, ''Geochemistry of Evaporitic Lacustrine Deposits''. Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences. v. 8, pp. 35–63.</ref><ref name="SpencerOthers1985">Spencer, R.J., Eugster, H.P., and Jones, B.F., 1985, ''Geochemistry of Great Salt Lake, Utah II: Pleistocene-Holocene evolution''. Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta. v. 49, no. 3, pp. 739–747.</ref><ref name="HartOthers2004">Hart, W.F., J. Quade, D.B. Madsen, D.S. Kaufman, and C.G. Oviatt, 2004, ''The 87Sr/86Sr ratios of lacustrine carbonates and lake-level history of the Bonneville paleolake system''. Geological Society of America Bulletin. v. 116, no. 9–10, pp. 1107–1119.</ref> Whether a lake becomes salty or not simply depends on whether the lake lacks an outlet and the relative balance between water flowing into the lake and leaving the lake via evaporation.<ref name="EugesterOthers1980"/> Ocean water dumped into a lake as the result of a single catastrophic event, as suggested above, would contain an inadequate amount of dissolved minerals to produce, when evaporated, the vast quantities of salts and other evaporites found in the salt lakes, flats, and pans cited as evidence of a mega-[[tsunami]] by this hypothesis.
==Geological criticism==
===Isostatic rebound=== Many published papers<ref name="Peltier1998">Peltier, W.R. 1998, ''Global glacial isostatic adjustment and coastal tectonics'' in I. Stewart and C. Vita-Finzi, eds., pp. 1–29. Coastal Tectonics. Special Publication no. 146, pp. 1–29. Geological Society of London, London.</ref><ref name="Peltier2002">Peltier, W.R., 2002, ''Global glacial isostatic adjustment: Palaeogeodetic and space-geodetic tests of the ICE-4G (VM2) model''. Journal of Quaternary Science. v. 17, no. 5–6, pp. 491–510.</ref> clearly demonstrate that [[isostatic depression]] of the [[Earth]]'s crust is not only real, but quite capable of submerging substantial portions of coastal areas adjacent to continental [[ice sheet]]s and resulting in the accumulations of [[Marine (ocean)|marine]] [[sediments]] and [[fossil]]s within them. A well-documented example of flooding caused by isostatic depression is the case of Charlotte, The Vermont Whale,<ref name="CharlotteWhale">Wright, W.A., 2000, [http://www.uvm.edu/whale/ ''Charlotte, The Vermont Whale An Electronic Museum.''] University of Vermont, Burlington, Vermont</ref> a fossil whale found in the deposits of the former [[Champlain Sea]]. Like many similar marine deposits, the sediments, which accumulated within the Champlain Sea lack the physical characteristics; i.e. sedimentary structures, interlayering, and textures, that characterize sediments deposited by a mega-[[tsunami]]. In addition, many of these deposits and the fossils, which they contain, are far too old, by hundreds to thousands of years, to have been created by impact around either 9,640 BP or 5,150 BP. In case of the Champlain Sea, its sediments started to accumulate around 13,000 BP, almost 3,400 years before the oldest of the hypothesized Holocene bolide impacts.<ref name="Hooper2001">Dr. Ken Hooper Virtual Natural History Museum Ottawa–Carleton Geoscience Centre, 2002, [http://hoopermuseum.earthsci.carleton.ca/2001_champlain2_mb/history.htm ''History of the Champlain Sea.''] Dept. of Earth Sciences, Carleton University.</ref>
===Dating=== As noted above, a significant amount of the physical evidence used by Kristan-Tollmann and Tollmann<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994"/> to argue for this [[Holocene]] impact is either too old or too young to have been created by this hypothesized impact. In many cases, it is hundreds to thousands, and in one case hundreds of thousands, of years too old to be credible evidence of a Holocene impact. For example, the research<ref name="Glass1978"/><ref name="Izokh1988"/><ref name="PrasadOthers1990"/> that dates the [[tektite]]s, which Tollmann bolide hypothesis regards as indicating the time of the hypothesized impact, is antiquated. Later research,<ref name="SchneiderOthers1992">Schneider, D.A., D.V. Kent, G.A. Mello, 1992, ''A detailed chronology of the Australasian impact event, the Brunhes–Matuyama geomagnetic polarity reversal, and global climatic change''. Earth and Planetary Science Letters . v. 111, no. 2–4, pp. 395–405.</ref><ref name="ShoemakerOthers1999">Shoemaker E.M., and H.R. Uhlherr, 1999, ''Stratigraphic relations of australites in the Port Campbell Embayment, Victoria''. Meteoritics & Planetary Science. v. 34, no. 3, pp. 369–384.</ref><ref name="LeeOthers2000">Lee, M.-Y., and K.-Y. Wei, 2000, ''Australasian microtektites in the South China Sea and the West Philippine Sea: Implications for age, size, and location of the impact crater''. Meteoritics & Planetary Science. v. 35, pp. 1151–1155.</ref> has shown the tektites to be far too old, about 790,000 BP in case of the Australasian tektites, to have been associated with any of his hypothesized Holocene impacts. At this time, there exist no documented examples of Holocene tektites. In addition, the formation of salt lakes and salt flats is neither synchronous nor consistent with the hypothesized impacts having occurred about either 9,640 BP or 5,150 BP. For example, in case of [[Lake Bonneville]], [[Lake Lahontan]], [[Mono Lake]], and other [[Pleistocene]] [[pluvial lake]]s in the western United States, the transition to salt lakes and salt flats occurred at different times between 12,000 and 16,000 BP.<ref name="BensonOthers2004">Benson, L., 2004, ''Western lakes'', in Gillespie, A.R., Porter, S.C., and Atwater, B., eds., p. 185–204. The Quaternary Period in the United States—Developments in Quaternary Science, Amsterdam, Elsevier. {{ISBN|0-444-51470-8}}</ref> Thus, the change from freshwater to salty water and eventually salt flats started over 2,400 to 6,400 years before the oldest of the impacts hypothesized by the Tollmann bolide hypothesis occurred. As a result, it impossible that the formation of these salt lakes could have been associated with the impact hypothesized by Kristan-Tollmann and Tollmann.<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994"/>
==Megatsunami== Finally, credible physical evidence of either multiple-kilometer-high [[tsunami]] waves penetrating deeply into continents and the ecological devastation they would have certainly caused have yet to be reported from any of the thousands of paleoenvironmental records constructed from the study of lakes, bogs, mires, and river valleys all over the world by [[palynology|palynologists]]. In the case of North America, various peer-reviewed publications<ref name="BryantOthers1985">Bryant, V.M., Jr., and R.G. Holloway, 1985, ''Pollen Records of Late-Quaternary North American Sediments''. Dallas, American Association of Stratigraphic Palynologists. {{ISBN|0-931871-01-8}}</ref><ref name="JacobsonOthers1987">Jacobson, G.L., Jr., T. Webb, III, and E.E. Grimm, 1987, ''Patterns and rates of vegetational change during the deglaciation of North America''. in W. F. Ruddiman and H. E. Wright, Jr., eds., pp. 277-287. North America Adjacent Oceans During the Last Deglaciation. The Geology of North America. K-3. Geological Society of America, Boulder, Colorado.</ref><ref name="ShumanOthers2002">Shuman, B., P. Bartlein, N. Logar, P. Newby, T. Webb, III, 2002, ''Parallel climate and vegetation responses to the early Holocene collapse of the Laurentide Ice Sheet''. Quaternary Science Reviews. v. 21, no. 16–17, pp. 1793-–805.</ref><ref name="GrimmOthers2004">Grimm, E.C. and G.L. Jacobson, Jr., 2004, ''Late Quaternary vegetation history of the eastern United States''. in Gillespie, A.R., S.C. Porter, and B.F. Atwater, eds., pp. 381–402. The Quaternary Period in the United States—Developments in Quaternary Science, Amsterdam, Elsevier. {{ISBN|0-444-51470-8}}</ref> summarize numerous published scientific papers that provide detailed records of paleoenvironmental changes that have occurred throughout the last 10,000 to 15,000 years as reconstructed from [[pollen]] and other paleoenvironmental data from over a thousand sites throughout [[North America]]. In none of these records, have palynologists recognized any indication of either the catastrophic environmental devastation or layers of [[tsunami deposit]]s, which the [[mega-tsunami]]s postulated by the Tollmann bolide hypothesis would have created. Paleovegetation maps<ref name="ShumanOthers2002"/><ref name="OverpeckOthers1992">Overpeck, J.T., R.S. Webb, and T. Webb., 1992. ''Mapping eastern North American vegetation change over the past 18,000 years: no-analogs and the future''. Geology. v. 20, no. 12, pp. 1071-1074.</ref> illustrate a distinct lack of the dramatic changes in North American paleovegetation during the Holocene, which would be expected from the cataclysmic ecological and physical destruction that a continental-wide mega-tsunamis would have certainly have caused.
For example, E. C. Grimm G. L. Jacobson and others<ref name="GrimmOthers1993">Grimm, E.C., G.L. Jacobson Jr., W.A. Watts, B.C.S. Hansen, and K.A. Maasch, 1993, ''A 50,000-Year Record of Climate Oscillations from Florida and Its Temporal Correlation with the Heinrich Events.'' Science. v. 261, no. 5118, pp. 198–200.</ref> documented a 50,000-year-long record of environmental change by the analysis of pollen from an {{convert|18.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} core from [[Lake Tulane]] in [[Highlands County, Florida|Highland county]], [[Florida]]. Because of the low-lying nature of the peninsula, in which this part of Florida lies, this lake and the area around it certainly would have been flooded and obliterated along with many of the other lakes and bogs described in their<ref name="GrimmOthers1993"/> and other publications.<ref name="JacobsonOthers1987"/> The forests and associated ecosystems of these areas would have been flooded and completely obliterated by the mega-tsunamis proposed by Kristan-Tollmann and Tollmann.<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994"/> Despite its location, both the core and the pollen record recovered from Lake Tulane completely lacks any indication of any abrupt, catastrophic environmental disruptions,<ref name="GrimmOthers1993"/> which the mega-tsunamis proposed by the Tollmann bolide hypothesis would have caused. This and other cores from Florida and elsewhere also lack sedimentary layers that have the characteristics of sediments deposited by either tsunamis or mega-tsunamis.
The cataclysmic scale of physical and ecological destruction that a megatsunami, like the one proposed by Kristan-Tollmann and Tollmann,<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994"/> would have caused to the Holocene landscape and ecosystems certainly would have left an obvious and readily recognizable signature within the majority of long-term environmental records. Such a signature has not been reported from the more than thousand cores from North America for which Holocene paleoclimatic and paleoenvironmental records have been reconstructed. There is a similar lack of evidence for mega-tsunami related, Holocene, catastrophic environmental disruptions and deposits reported from environmental records reconstructed from thousands of locations from all over the world. This lack of a physical record for the occurrence of Holocene mega-tsunamis is quite revealing given that geologists and palynologists have been quite successful in some coastal regions finding in cores and exposures the characteristic [[sediments]] deposited by tsunamis locally generated by either [[earthquake]]s, [[volcanic eruption]]s, or submarine slides and recovering abundant well-defined records of their environmental effects by studying the pollen from cores and exposures.
Members of the [[Holocene Impact Working Group]] have published papers advocating the occurrence of mega-tsunamis created by extraterrestrial impacts at various times during the Holocene and Late Pleistocene.<ref name="Blakeslee">Blakeslee, S., 2006, [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/14/science/14WAVE.html?8dpc ''Ancient Crash, Epic Wave.''] New York Times, November 14, 2006.</ref> However, none of these proposed impacts match either the cataclysmic scale or timing proposed by Kristan-Tollmann and Tollmann<ref name="Kristan-TollmannOthers1994"/> for Alexander Tollmann's bolide.
==See also== * [[Holocene extinction event]] * [[Extinction event]] * [[Impact event]] * [[Timeline of environmental events]] * ''[[Uriel's Machine]]''
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *Pinter, N., and S.E. Ishman, 2008, [http://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/18/1/pdf/i1052-5173-18-1-37.pdf ''Impacts, mega-tsunami, and other extraordinary claims'' PDF version, 304 KB]. GSA Today. vol. 18, no. 1, pp. 37–38.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tollmann's Hypothetical Bolide}} [[Category:Historical geology]] [[Category:Hypothetical impact events]] [[Category:Extinction events]]

revision.comment: new headers (more current), moved some content to fit headers
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Victor Riesel |image = Victor Riesel - before and after.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Victor Riesel in 1956, before and after the acid attack which left him blind |birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|03|26}}<ref>''Town Meeting: Bulletin of America's Town Meeting of the Air,'' 1952, p. 34.</ref> |birth_place = [[Lower East Side]], [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States |death_date = {{Death date and age|1995|01|04|1913|03|26}}<ref name="obitNYT">{{cite news|first=Van |last=Gelder |title=Victor Riesel, 81, Columnist Blinded by Acid Attack, Dies |newspaper=New York Times |date=January 5, 1995 |accessdate=2013-06-06 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/05/obituaries/victor-riesel-81-columnist-blinded-by-acid-attack-dies.html}}</ref> |death_place = Manhattan, New York City, New York, U.S. |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = Journalist, syndicated columnist |nationality = American }}
'''Victor Riesel''' ({{IPAc-en|r|ᵻ|ˈ|z|ɛ|l}};<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /> March 26, 1913 – January 4, 1995) was an [[United States|American]] [[newspaper]] [[journalist]] and [[columnist]] who specialized in [[news]] related to [[Trade union|labor unions]]. At the height of his career, his column on labor union issues was [[Print syndication|syndicated]] to 356 newspapers in the [[United States]].<ref name="Riley">Riley, ''Biographical Dictionary of American Newspaper Columnists,'' 1995, p. 265.</ref> In an incident which made national headlines for almost a year,<ref name="Gross">Gross, ''Broken Promise: The Subversion of U.S. Labor Relations Policy, 1947–1994,'' 1995, p. 138.</ref> a [[gangster]] threw [[sulfuric acid]] in his face on a public street in [[New York City]] on April 5, 1956, causing his permanent [[blindness]].<ref name="RaskinThug">Raskin, "Thug Hurls Acid on Labor Writer," ''New York Times,'' April 6, 1956.</ref><ref name="LosesSight">"Riesel Loses Sight From Burns of Acid." ''New York Times.'' May 5, 1956.</ref>
==Background== Victor Riesel was born on the [[Lower East Side]] of [[Manhattan]] in [[New York City]] to Nathan and Sophie Riesel.<ref name="Tears">"Tears of Jobless Inspired Riesel," ''New York Times,'' April 6, 1956.</ref><ref name="Nissenson">Nissenson, ''The Lady Upstairs: Dorothy Schiff and the New York Post,'' 2007, p. 119.</ref><ref name="Hamill">Hamill, "The Lives They Lived: Victor Riesel and Walter Sheridan: In Defense of Honest Labor," ''New York Times,'' December 31, 1995.</ref><ref name="AnswerByAcid">"The Press: Answer by Acid," ''Time,'' April 16, 1956.</ref><ref name="Sophie">"Mrs. Sopie Riesel," ''New York Times,'' May 31, 1966.</ref> The family lived in a [[cold water flat]] near the [[IRT Second Avenue Line|elevated railroad]] tracks.<ref name="Marks" /> The Riesels were [[Jews|Jewish]], and their neighbors were primarily Jewish and [[Italian American]].<ref name="Marks" /> Victor's father, Nathan, had helped organize the Bonnaz, Singer, and Hand Embroiderers' Union, Local 66, of the [[International Ladies Garment Workers Union]] in 1913,<ref name="Marks">Marks, "12 Who Made It Big," Newman Library, Baruch College, no date.</ref><ref>See, generally, ILGWU, ''The Fight's Just Begun: Fifty Years with Local 66, 1913–1963,'' 1963.</ref> and held the Card No. 1 in the local union.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="RieselFatherobit">Riesel, "Remembering the Crusade," ''Miami News,'' March 6, 1947.</ref> In time, Nathan Riesel was appointed a staff member of the union and elected secretary-treasurer and then president of the local union.<ref name="Nissenson" /><ref>"Embroiderers Ratify Call for Walkout," ''New York Times,'' August 23, 1929; "Embroidery Strike Likely Next Week," ''New York Times,'' September 4, 1931.</ref> Victor attended [[elementary school]] at [[List of public elementary schools in New York City#Region 2: The Bronx|P.S. 19]] (now the Judith K. Weiss School).<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Hamill" /><ref name="Marks" />
When Victor was three years old, his father taught him to make pro-union speeches and would take his son to rallies and union meetings and have the boy recite the speeches for onlookers.<ref name="Hamill" /><ref name="Marks" /><ref name="Maeder">Maeder, "Dark Places: Victor Riesel, 1956," ''New York Daily News,'' September 22, 1998.</ref> Attending union meetings, indoor and outdoor rallies, and standing on street corners promoting the union formed many of Victor Riesel's childhood and teenage memories.<ref name="Tears" /><ref name="RieselFatherobit" /> In the 1920s and 1930s, Nathan Riesel successfully opposed [[Communist Party USA]] attempts to infiltrate activists into the local union and turning its purpose to promotion of the party (a strategy known as "[[boring from within]]").<ref name="Marks" /><ref>For a history of the "boring from within" strategy, see, generally: Foner, ''History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Vol. 9: The T.U.E.L. to the End of the Gompers Era,'' 1991; Foner, ''History of the Labor Movement in the United States. Vol. 10: The T.U.E.L., 1925–1929,'' 1994.</ref> Throughout his childhood and teenage years, he saw his father come home bleeding many times after fistfights with communist activists or gangsters.<ref name="AnswerByAcid" /> This conflict left a deep impression on Victor.<ref name="RieselFatherobit" />
The family moved to the [[Bronx]] when Riesel was 13 years old.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Hamill" /><ref name="Marks" /> Academically gifted, Victor Riesel graduated from [[Morris High School (Bronx, New York)|Morris High School]] at the age of 15.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Hamill" /> While in high school, Riesel began typing stories about the American labor movement and sending them to English language newspapers around the world, charging $1 for publication rights.<ref name="Marks" /> He typed the same story over and over (sometimes as many as 15 times) to make it look like an original (his goal being to sell the same story to many newspapers rather than many stories to a single newspaper), and earned a significant income from this work.<ref name="Marks" />
He enrolled in [[City College of New York]] (CCNY) in 1928, taking classes at night in human resource management and industrial relations.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Maeder" />
==Career==
Riesel worked several different jobs to support himself, and found employment in a hat factory, lace plant, steel mill, and saw mill.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Riley" /><ref name="Hamill" /><ref name="Maeder" /> He was appointed director of undergraduate publications at the college, working as an [[Editing#Print media|editor]], columnist, and literature and theatre critic.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Hamill" /> He earned his [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] from CCNY in 1940.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Riley" /><ref name="Hamill" /><ref name="Marks" />
During his undergraduate years at CCNY, Riesel began working as a gofer at ''[[The New Leader]]''.<ref name="Marks" /> After graduation in 1940, he became the magazine's managing editor.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Marks" /><ref name="Maeder" />
Two additional events in Riesel's life led him to a career as a labor reporter. The first occurred on March 6, 1930, during a visit to his father's union offices. Riesel saw a man weeping on the stairs because he had no job and his family had no food to eat.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Marks" /><ref name="Maeder" /> The second occurred in 1942. Nathan Riesel was now fighting [[organized crime]] influence in his union, and despaired of keeping his local out of criminal hands.<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="Marks" /><ref name="RieselFatherobit" /> Nathan Riesel was severely beaten by gangsters in 1942, and died five years later (in part due to the injuries suffered during and surgeries related to this attack).<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="Nissenson" /><ref name="Marks" /><ref name="RieselFatherobit" /><ref name="Maeder" />
===Journalism=== Victor Riesel's labor journalism career formally began in 1937 when he started writing a regular column on labor union issues.<ref name="Riley" /><ref name="Nissenson" />
He was hired by ''[[The New York Post]]'' in 1941.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="Riley" /><ref name="Nissenson" /> His column became nationally syndicated in 1942.<ref name="Riley" /><ref name="Nissenson" /><ref name="Maeder" /> He left the ''Post'' in 1948 after a change in management, and joined [[William Randolph Hearst]]'s ''[[New York Daily Mirror]]''.<ref name="Riley" /><ref name="Nissenson" /> Within eight years, his column was syndicated in 193 newspapers.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Tears" /><ref name="AnswerByAcid" /><ref name="Maeder" />
His investigation of Communist Party infiltration of the [[National Maritime Union]] led [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Louis B. Heller]] to introduce legislation in 1951 to investigate the charges.<ref name="Maeder" /> In 1951 and 1952, Riesel provided [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Pat McCarran]] with information that led to a Senate investigation into communist influence in the [[United Public Workers of America]].<ref name="Maeder" /> In 1952, he publicly alleged before the [[United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security|Subcommittee on Internal Security]] (led at the time by Sen. McCarran) that Local 65 of the [[Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America]] was controlled by the Communist Party.<ref name="Maeder" /> The same year, he denounced [[Gambino crime family]] member [[Anthony Anastasio|Anthony "Tough Tony" Anastasio]] for engaging in [[Racket (crime)|labor racketeering]].<ref name="Maeder" /> Anastasio sued Riesel for $1 million for [[libel]], but the suit was thrown out of court.<ref name="Maeder" />
On February 6, 1953, Riesel spoke with New York University philosophy professor [[Sidney Hook]] and others on "The Threat to Academic Freedom" in the evening on [[WEVD]] radio.<ref> {{cite news | title = On the Radio | publisher = New York Times | url = | page = 26 | date = 6 February 1953 | accessdate = 3 September 2018}}</ref>
In 1956, Riesel began working with [[United States Attorney]] Paul Williams to rein in labor racketeering in the New York City garment and trucking industries.<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="AnswerByAcid" /><ref name="Maeder" />
===Acid attack=== On April 5, 1956, an assailant threw [[sulphuric acid]] into Riesel's face as he was leaving [[Lindy's]] (a famous restaurant in Manhattan). Riesel had been reporting on corruption in the [[International Union of Operating Engineers]] and its then-President, [[William C. DeKoning, Jr.]]<ref name="RaskinThug" /> He had recently alleged that DeKoning was conspiring with [[Joseph S. Fay]] (a convicted labor racketeer and [[extortion]]ist) to re-establish his father, [[William C. DeKoning, Sr.]] (who had recently been freed from prison after serving a sentence for extortion) as president of the union.<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="AnswerByAcid" /> Although Riesel had received numerous death and other threats over the past few months, he had dismissed them as the work of "cranks."<ref name="RaskinThug" />
The attack occurred shortly after a Riesel radio broadcast. [[Barry Gray (radio)|Barry Gray]], radio station [[WMCA (AM)|WMCA]]'s overnight [[talk radio]] host, had asked Riesel to substitute for him.<ref name="AnswerByAcid" /><ref name="Maeder" /> Riesel invited two IUOE Local 138 leaders who were challenging the DeKonings for control of the local union to join him for the broadcast.<ref name="AnswerByAcid" /><ref name="Maeder" /> The broadcast originated from Hutton's Restaurant at [[47th Street (Manhattan)|47th Street]] and [[Lexington Avenue (Manhattan)|Lexington Avenue]] shortly after midnight on April 5, and concluded at 2 AM.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> Afterward, Riesel and his secretary went to Lindy's restaurant, located on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] between 49th Street and [[50th Street (Manhattan)|50th Street]].<ref name="RaskinThug" /> They had coffee, and departed Lindy's at 3 AM to walk to the secretary's automobile.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> Riesel removed his eyeglasses, which he did by habit when in public.<ref name="AnswerByAcid" /> A slender, black-haired man in blue and white jacket stepped out of the shadows of the entrance to the [[Mark Hellinger Theatre]] and threw a vial of sulphuric acid into Riesel's eyes.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> Riesel shouted, "My gosh! My gosh!", and clutched at his face.<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="AnswerByAcid" /> While the secretary and others rendered assistance and dragged Riesel into Lindy's, the assailant walked calmly away.<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="AnswerByAcid" />
The acid struck Riesel's right eye more than the left.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> Riesel's eyes were flushed with water inside Lindy's, but patrons stopped administering aid for fear of doing further damage.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> Riesel was taken to St. Clare's Hospital on East 71st Street, where doctors worked to save his vision.<ref name="RaskinThug" /><ref name="AnswerByAcid" /> Measures to counteract the acid were not taken until Riesel arrived at St. Clare's, 40 minutes after the attack.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> On May 4, doctors said that Riesel had completely lost his sight (see the right photograph in the infobox, above).<ref name="LosesSight" /> In December 1956, Riesel described the amount of acid as a "deluge" which covered most of his cheeks, eyes, and forehead.<ref name="Gross" /><ref name="RanzalStand">Ranzal, "Riesel, on the Stand, Describes How Acid 'Deluge' Hit His Eyes," ''New York Times,'' December 4, 1956.</ref><ref>In fact, there was so much acid thrown that some of it splashed back onto attacker Abraham Telvi's face. Telvi's scars made him easily identifiable as Riesel's assailant. When Telvi demanded another $50,000 as compensation for remaining in hiding and staying quiet in the case, the Genovese crime family had him killed. See: Levey, "F.B.I. Solves Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' August 18, 1956; Perlmutter, "Body Is Exhumed In Riesel Inquiry," ''New York Times,'' August 22, 1956; "Body of Hoodlum Examined Anew," ''New York Times,'' August 23, 1956; "Johnny Dio and 4 Others Held As Masterminds in Riesel Attack," ''New York Times,'' August 29, 1956; Perlmutter, "Dio Linked By U.S. To Telvi Murder in Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' August 30, 1956.</ref> Portions of Riesel's face (see right photo, above, compared to left photo, particularly the left cheek, jaw line, and jowls; the eyebrows; and the forehead) were permanently scarred as well.<ref name="Gross" /><ref>"Governor Visits Riesel's Bedside," ''New York Times,'' April 9, 1956.</ref> Riesel wore dark glasses for the rest of his life to hide his damaged eyes, which many people found difficult to look at.<ref name="RanzalStand" />
The ''Daily Mirror'' immediately offered a $10,000 reward for information identifying the assailant and leading to his conviction.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> The [[The Newspaper Guild|Newspaper Guild of New York]], [[New York Press Photographers Association]], [[Overseas Press Club]], New York Newspaper Reporters Association, and the Society of Silurians (an organization of veteran New York City journalists) immediately raised the reward to $15,000.<ref name="RaskinThug" /> By week's end, donations from labor unions, radio station WMCA, and other groups had increased the reward to $41,000.<ref name="AnswerByAcid" />
The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) identified [[Abraham Telvi]] as the assailant in August 1956, but Telvi had been murdered on July 28, 1956, by mobsters for demanding an additional $50,000 on top of the $500 he had already received for the crime.<ref name="Frankel">Frankel, "Johnny Dio and 4 Others Held As Masterminds in Riesel Attack," ''New York Times,'' August 29, 1956.</ref><ref>Levey, "F.B.I. Solves Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' August 18, 1956.</ref> On August 29, 1956, Genovese crime family [[underboss]] [[Johnny Dio]] was arrested for conspiracy in the Riesel attack, pleaded not guilty, and was released on $100,000 bond even though prosecutors later publicly linked him to the Telvi murder.<ref>Levey, "U.S. Hints New Lead In Attack on Riesel," ''New York Times,'' August 19, 1956; Perlmutter, "Dio Linked By U.S. To Telvi Murder in Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' August 30, 1956; "Reprisal Feared for Dio's Arrest," ''New York Times,'' August 31, 1956; "Hogan Gets Data in Riesel Inquiry," ''New York Times,'' September 1, 1956; Levey, "Rackets and Crime Linked in Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' September 2, 1956; Ranzal, "Court Cautions U.S. To Speed Dio Case," ''New York Times,'' September 6, 1956; Ranzal, "Jury Indicts Dio in Riesel Attack," ''New York Times,'' September 8, 1956; "Dio and Four Deny Guilt in Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' September 11, 1956; "Bond of $100,000 Is Posted By Dio," ''New York Times,'' October 11, 1956; "Indictment of Dio Upheld By Court," ''New York Times,'' October 16, 1956.</ref>
Joseph Carlino, a Dio associate who had hired Telvi to attack Riesel, pleaded guilty on October 22, and prosecutors severed Dio's trial from the others.<ref>Stengren, "Guilty Plea Made By Riesel Suspect," ''New York Times,'' October 23, 1956; "2 Trials Granted in Riesel Attack," ''New York Times,'' November 8, 1956.</ref> Carlino later testified that Dio had ordered Genovese mob associate Gandolfo Miranti to find a hitman and identify Riesel, and that Miranti had contacted Dominick Bando to assist him in finding the hitman (Bando contacting Carlino, who sought out Telvi).<ref name="Maeder" /><ref>"The Fall-Out," ''Time,'' August 27, 1956; "The Team Behind Telvi," ''Time,'' September 10, 1956; Ranzal, "Jury Hears Story of Riesel Attack," ''New York Times,'' November 15, 1956; Ranzal, "Dio Directed Attack On Riesel, Trial Told," ''New York Times,'' November 28, 1956.</ref> Miranti and Bando were then found guilty (Bando pleading guilty at the last moment).<ref>Freeman, "3 Convicted of Plot In Riesel Blinding," ''New York Times,'' December 7, 1956; "Guilty Plea Filed in Riesel Attack," ''New York Times,'' January 26, 1957; ''United States v. Miranti,'' 253 F.2d 135 (1958).</ref> Conspiracy charges against Dio were later dropped despite the convictions. Dio's attorney delayed the trial for nearly five months with motions.<ref>"Riesel-Case Trial of Dio Is Delayed," ''New York Times,'' April 25, 1957.</ref> When the trial finally began, Carlino and Miranti recanted their pre-trial statements and courtroom testimony, claiming they did not know who had ordered the attack on Riesel.<ref>Becker, "Key Dio Witness Refuses to Talk," ''New York Times,'' May 21, 1957; Ranzal, "Dio Case Dropped From Court Docket," ''New York Times,'' May 28, 1957.</ref> By September 1957, the government no longer sought to prosecute Dio for the attack.<ref>"Judge Continues Dio's Indictment," ''New York Times,'' September 24, 1957.</ref> Miranti received 8 to 16 years in prison and Bando 2 to 5 years in prison for the acid attack and another five years for [[contempt of court]].<ref>"2 In Riesel Case Get Long Terms," ''New York Times,'' February 22, 1957; Ranzal, "Silent in Dio Case, Thug Gets 5 Years," ''New York Times,'' May 25, 1957.</ref> Carlino received a suspended sentence for cooperating with the prosecution,<ref>"Freed in Riesel Case," ''New York Times,'' December 14, 1957.</ref> and three other co-conspirators were freed after the judge in their case declared a [[mistrial (law)|mistrial]].<ref>"Acid Throwing Case Called A Mistrial," ''New York Times,'' July 6, 1960.</ref> The ''Daily Mirror'' paid one witness $5,000 in 1961 for information leading to the identification of Abraham Telvi as the assailant.<ref>"Mirror Pays Reward," ''New York Times,'' March 31, 1961.</ref>
The attack on Riesel had significant implications for national American labor policy. [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight Eisenhower]] (who had seen Riesel on ''[[Meet the Press]]'') told [[AFL-CIO]] President [[George Meany]] that he was so incensed by the attack on Riesel that he intended to introduce legislation designed to root out corruption in labor unions.<ref name="Gross" /><ref>"Eisenhower to Act on Union Rackets," ''New York Times,'' June 6, 1956; Ball, ''Meet the Press: Fifty Years of History in the Making,'' 1998, p. 1955.</ref> [[Clark R. Mollenhoff]], editor of the ''[[Des Moines Register]]'', was so alarmed by the attack on Riesel that he ordered extensive investigations into trade union corruption.<ref name="Hilty">Hilty, ''Robert Kennedy: Brother Protector,'' 2000, p. 100.</ref> Mollenhoff's investigative efforts unearthed much evidence that [[Teamsters]] President [[Jimmy Hoffa]] was engaged in labor racketeering.<ref name="Hilty"/> The attack also convinced [[Robert F. Kennedy]], then chief legal counsel for the [[United States Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs|Senate Committee on Government Operations]], to lead an investigation into labor racketeering.<ref name="Hilty" /> Kennedy's investigations (as well as subsequent labor scandals) led to the establishment of the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in Labor and Management|Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in Labor and Management]].<ref name="Hilty" /><ref name="Lichtenstein">Lichtenstein, ''State of the Union: A Century of American Labor,'' 2003, p. 163.</ref> This committee's investigations led directly to the passage of the [[Labor Management Reporting and Disclosure Act]], which imposed financial reporting requirements on labor unions, limited the power of trusteeships, established many member and employer rights, and created additional [[unfair labor practice]]s governing unions.<ref name="Lichtenstein" />
The acid attack vastly boosted Riesel's national popularity. He began a regular [[television program]] on WRCA-TV, and a regular weekly radio program on [[WWRV|WEVD]].<ref>Adams, "Air Shows Slated for Victor Riesel," ''New York Times,'' June 13, 1956.</ref> He continued to write his column, typing it himself while his wife read newspapers and [[News agency|wire service]] articles to him.<ref name="obitNYT" />
===Anti-communist views=== Riesel was a militant anti-[[Communism|communist]]. Initially, his views focused on both [[fascism]] and [[communism]]. As early as 1939, he joined [[John Dewey]]'s newly formed [[Committee for Cultural Freedom]], which was opposed to [[totalitarianism]] in all its forms.<ref>"New Group Fights Any Freedom Curb," ''New York Times,'' May 15, 1939.</ref> In 1941, he told the [[Union for Democratic Action]] that Rep. [[Martin Dies, Jr.]] was intent on establishing a national fascist police force to suppress freedom of speech in the United States.<ref>"Dies Called Creator of Political Police," ''New York Times,'' July 29, 1942.</ref>
Riesel's attacks on fascism lessened after World War II, and he focused almost exclusively on communism after 1950. Riesel's attacks on communism extended beyond labor unions. He attacked [[American folk music revival|folk musician]] [[Vern Partlow]] for promoting communism and undermining American national security with his 1945 [[talking blues]] song "Atomic Talking Blues" (also known as "Talking Atom" and "Old Man Atom").<ref>Cohen, ''Rainbow Quest: The Folk Music Revival and American Society, 1940–1970,'' 2002, p. 85.</ref> In 1949, he was named a director of the [[Committee to Defend America by Aiding Anti-Communist China]], a part of the [[China Lobby]].<ref>Tucker, ''Patterns in the Dust: Chinese-American Relations and the Recognition Controversy, 1949–1950,'' 1983, p. 255, fn. 35.</ref> At least one author alleges that Riesel even cooperated with the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] beginning in the early 1950s, providing information on liberal politicians and union leaders.<ref>Wilford, ''The Mighty Wurlitzer: How the CIA Played America,'' 2008, p. 246.</ref> In the early 1950s, he supported a movement to stop the importation of goods from the [[Soviet Union]] into the United States, and for a time [[Stevedore|longshoremen]] on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] refused to unload Soviet ships due to Riesel's campaign.<ref name="Riley" /> During the height of [[McCarthyism]] in the early 1950s, he also became interested in purging [[Homosexuality|homosexuals]] from federal civil service.<ref>Nasaw, ''The Chief: The Life of William Randolph Hearst,'' 2001, p. 597.</ref> He publicly called for a "preventive war" with the Soviet Union in 1951, and demanded that President [[Harry S. Truman]] drop the [[Nuclear weapon|atomic bomb]] on Russia and [[China]].<ref>Roberts and Olson, ''John Wayne: American,'' 1995, p. 347.</ref> He strongly criticized [[Malcolm X]] for meeting with [[Shirley Graham Du Bois]] and [[Julian Mayfield]] in the mid-1960s, and accused Malcolm X of fomenting communist conspiracies.<ref>Joseph, ''Waiting 'til the Midnight Hour: A Narrative History of Black Power in America,'' 2007, p. 112; Horne, ''Race Woman: The Lives of Shirley Graham Du Bois,'' 2000, p. 187.</ref> In the early 1970s, Riesel became an unofficial advisor to President [[Richard Nixon]]. He supported Nixon in his column, discussed labor union issues and outreach to working-class voters with him personally over the phone, and occasionally met with [[United States Cabinet|Cabinet]] members.<ref>Sidey, "This Is the White House Calling," ''Life,'' April 2, 1971, p. 28; Liebovich, ''Richard Nixon, Watergate and the Press: A Historical Retrospective,'' 2003, p. 11.</ref> Even as late as 1973, Riesel was defending [[COINTELPRO]], a series of [[Covert operation|covert]] and often illegal projects conducted by the FBI aimed at investigating and disrupting [[Dissident|dissident political organizations]] in the U.S.<ref>Wannall, ''The Real J. Edgar Hoover: For the Record,'' 2000, p. 82.</ref>
Riesel was intimately involved in the [[Hollywood blacklist]] of the late 1940s and 1950s. He strongly criticized [[Samuel Fuller]]'s 1951 [[Korean War]] [[film]] ''[[The Steel Helmet]]'' for promoting communism and portraying American soldiers as murderers.<ref>Chung, ''Hollywood Asian: Philip Ahn and the Politics of Cross-Ethnic Performance,'' 2006, p. 125-126.</ref> He also attacked the 1954 pro-union film ''[[Salt of the Earth (1954 film)|Salt of the Earth]]'' as communistic, and implied that the production's on-location proximity to [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] and the [[Nevada Test Site]] was a cover for Soviet spying on the American nuclear weapons program.<ref>Lorence, ''The Suppression of 'Salt of the Earth': How Hollywood, Big Labor, and Politicians Blacklisted a Movie in Cold War America,'' 1999, p. 78; Biberman, ''Salt of the Earth: The Story of a Film,'' 2003, p. 88; Whitfield, ''The Culture of the Cold War,'' 1996, p. 145.</ref> Riesel saw it as his patriotic duty to publicize allegations of communist influence made against actors, directors, producers, and others (especially those claims made by conservative actors [[Adolphe Menjou]] and [[Ward Bond]]).<ref>Baughman, ''The Republic of Mass Culture: Journalism, Filmmaking, and Broadcasting in America Since 1941,'' 2006, p. 38; Pells, ''The Liberal Mind in a Conservative Age: American Intellectuals in the 1940s and 1950s,'' 1989, p. 307.</ref><ref name="Navasky">Navasky, "HUAC in Hollywood," in ''Hollywood: Social Dimensions: Technology, Regulation and the Audience,'' 2004, p. 321.</ref> As the blacklist lifted, Riesel agreed to allow his column to become a means for blacklisted individuals to admit their offenses, denounce communism, and become active in the motion picture industry again. Along with [[Hedda Hopper]] and [[Walter Winchell]], he would meet privately with these individuals, assess the sincerity of their [[penance]], and then work with them to help rehabilitate their careers if he believed they were being honest with him.<ref name="Navasky" /><ref name="Blacklist">Bernstein, ''Inside Out: A Memoir of the Blacklist,'' 2000, p. 153; Rose, ''The Agency: William Morris and the Hidden History of Show Business,'' 1996, p. 156; Ceplair and Englund, ''The Inquisition in Hollywood: Politics in the Film Community, 1930–60,'' 2003, p. 389; Lichtman and Cohen, ''Deadly Farce: Harvey Matusow and the Informer System in the McCarthy Era,'' 2004, p. 64.</ref>
===Later life=== Victor Riesel retired from the ''Daily Mirror'' in 1963 but continued to publish his syndicated column.<ref name="Riley" /> Three men who leased coin-operated pool tables to establishments in California sued Riesel for libel in 1965, alleging that his column on racketeering in the vending industry defamed them.<ref>"Coinmen Sue Columnist," ''Billboard,'' April 17, 1965, p. 46.</ref>
Riesel was elected a director of the Overseas Press Club in 1962, and the organization's president in 1966 (he served a single one-year term).<ref name="Sophie" /><ref>"Overseas Press Club Elects New Officers," ''New York Times,'' May 1, 1962.</ref>
Riesel retired his column in 1990.<ref name="obitNYT" /><ref name="Hamill" />
==Personal and death==
Riesel married the former Evelyn Lobelson after graduating from college.<ref name="obitNYT" /> The couple had a son, Michael, in 1942 and a daughter, Susan, in 1949.<ref name="Tears" />
Riesel died of [[cardiac arrest]] at his apartment in Manhattan aged 81.<ref name="obitNYT" /> His wife, son, and daughter survived him.<ref name="obitNYT" />

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- For individuals; see Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Wilkie Bard | image = Wilkie Bard.jpg | alt = | caption =<small>Bard as Widow Twanky in Aladdin, c. 1906</small> | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = William August Smith | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1874|3|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Chorlton-cum-Hardy]], [[Manchester]], [[England]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1944|5|5|1874|3|19|df=y}} | death_place = [[Buckinghamshire]], England | origin = | instrument = | genre = [[vaudeville]], [[music hall]] | occupation = | years_active = | label = | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Wilkie Bard''' (born '''William August Smith''') (19 March 1874 – 5 May 1944) was a popular British [[vaudeville]] and [[music hall]] entertainer and recording artist at the beginning of the 20th century. He is best known for his songs "I Want to Sing in Opera" and "The Night Watchman".
==Early life== Bard was born in [[Chorlton-cum-Hardy]], [[Manchester]], [[Lancashire]].<ref>"Old Music Halls", ''[[The Stage]]'', 21 January 1951, p. 4.</ref> He began as an amateur singer and comedian, aged 21, and his acts included the part of a [[Coon song|coon singer]]<ref name="SDE6">"Song on Balcony", ''Sunderland Daily Echo and Shipping Gazette'', 8 August 1939, p. 6.</ref> and a character who had a bald head and who wore a black spot on each eyebrow.<ref>"Excursions",''Worthing Herald'', 26 May 1939, pp. 17–18.</ref> He also performed in female character roles, specifically with his hit song "I Want to Sing in Opera".<ref>"Wilkie Bard: Dutchman. Mr. Wilkie Bard in "My Little Deutsche Girl", one of his littlest successes", ''Penny Illustrated Paper, 7 December 1907, p. 3.</ref> Bard had a long career in [[pantomime]]<ref name="SDE6" /> and introduced [[Tongue-twister|tongue twisters]] such as "She sells seashells by the seashore", based on a song he performed in the show "[[Dick Whittington and His Cat]]" in [[Drury Lane]] in 1908.{{cn|date=November 2017}} In 1919 he went to America where he performed in [[vaudeville]],<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9901E5D81F3AE633A25750C0A9609C946296D6CF&scp=5&sq=wilkie+bard&st=p "Hammerstein Signs Wilkie Bard"], ''New York Times'', 3 June 1913, p. 3.</ref> making his debut at the [[Palace Theatre (Broadway)|Palace Theatre]] on 20 October that year; the show was not well received.<ref>[http://article.archive.nytimes.com/1919/10/21/118168022.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAJBTN455PTTBQQNRQ&Expires=1511727766&Signature=%2FNTBW1tB0XkTegdPpfV6kSYloKA%3D "The Play by Alexander Woolcot], ''The New York Times'', 21 October 1919.</ref> He stayed with the production and after a few alterations to the script, he became a hit.<ref>[http://article.archive.nytimes.com/1919/10/24/118170735.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAJBTN455PTTBQQNRQ&Expires=1511728009&Signature=niRgp6EoOXoWRXXaP%2B4db%2FtN5SA%3D "Wilkie Bard Reappears"], ''The New York Times'', 24 October 1919.</ref>
He performed in [[Australia]] in 1921.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19210719&id=_Y8TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tZYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3124,1854412 "Wilkie Bard, famous English comedian here"], ''Sydney Morning Herald'', 19 July 1921, p. 12.</ref> In 1923, Bard appeared with [[Jack Pearl]] in tests for [[Lee de Forest]]'s sound-on-film process [[Phonofilm]]. This short film is in the collection of the [[UCLA Film and Television Archive]]. In 1928, Bard appeared in two short films made in Phonofilm, ''The Cleaner'' and ''The Night Watchman'', which may be in the collection of the [[British Film Institute]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6549917 IMDB entry]</ref>
==Personal life== Bard was married to Ellen Smith (née Stratton), who performed using the stage name Nellie Stratton. The 1881 and 1891 UK census returns show her name to be Nellie from birth (Peckham, London 1875).<ref>1891 UK census return RG12/119</ref>
==Death== Bard died in 1944 at the age of 70 in Buckinghamshire following a coronary thrombosis.<ref>"Death of Mr Wilkie Bard, ''Aberdeen Press and Journal'', 6 May 1944, p. 1.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|6549917}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bard, Wilkie}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:People from Chorlton-cum-Hardy]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox military person |name=William Richard Higgins |birth_date= {{birth date|1945|1|15}} |death_date= {{Death date and age|1990|7|6|1945|1|15}} |birth_place= [[Danville, Kentucky]], U.S. |death_place= [[Lebanon]] |placeofburial= [[Quantico National Cemetery]] |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image= HigginsWilliamR USMC.jpg |caption=William R. Higgins, USMC |nickname= Rich |allegiance= [[United States of America]] |branch= {{flag|United States Marine Corps}} |serviceyears=1967-1990 |rank= [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] |commands= |unit= |battles=[[Vietnam War]] |awards=[[Defense Distinguished Service Medal]]
[[Defense Superior Service Medal]]
[[Legion of Merit]]
[[Bronze Star Medal]]
[[Purple Heart]] |relations=LtCol [[Robin Higgins]], USMC, Ret. (spouse) }} '''William Richard Higgins''' (January 15, 1945 – July 6, 1990) was a [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] in the [[United States Marine Corps]] who was captured in 1988 while serving on a [[United Nations]] (UN) peacekeeping mission in [[Lebanon]]. He was held hostage, tortured{{cite news |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0607/29/cp.01.html |title=CNN PRESENTS — Encore Presentation: Inside Hezbollah |accessdate=2008-09-03 |author= |last=Cooper |first=Anderson |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2006-07-29 |year= |month= |work= |publisher=CNN.com |pages= |language= |doi= |quote=Hezbollah is a suspect in the torture and murder of U.S. Colonel William Higgins. Higgins disappeared in 1988, while leading a U.N. observer group in south Lebanon. A year and a half later, this video appeared on television screens around the world. Higgins, badly beaten body, hanging from a rope. }} and eventually murdered by his captors. ==Biography== William Higgins was born in [[Danville, Kentucky]] on January 15, 1945. He graduated from [[Southern High School (Kentucky)|Southern High School]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]] and earned his [[Bachelor's degree]] from [[Miami University]] in [[Oxford, Ohio]]. A [[scholarship]] student in the [[Navy ROTC]], he received the Marine Corps Association Award and was commissioned in the Marine Corps in 1967. He later obtained [[Master's degree]]s from [[Pepperdine University]] and [[Auburn University]]. He graduated from the [[United States Army|Army]] [[Infantry]] Officers Advanced Course, the [[Air Command and Staff College|Air Force Command and Staff College]], and the [[National War College]]. As a lieutenant, he participated in [[Vietnam War|combat operations during 1968]] with C Company, [[1st Battalion 3rd Marines]] in the [[South Vietnam|Republic of Vietnam]] as a rifle platoon commander and rifle company executive officer, and was aide-de-camp to the Assistant [[3rd Marine Division (United States)|3rd Marine Division]] Commander. Returning to the States, Lt. Higgins served at [[Headquarters Marine Corps]] in 1969. In 1970, he served as the Officer-in-Charge of the Officer Selection Team in Louisville, Kentucky. Captain Higgins returned to Vietnam in 1972 as an infantry battalion advisor to the [[Republic of Vietnam Marine Division|Vietnamese Marine Division]], then in 1973 served as a rifle company commander with B Company, [[1st Battalion 4th Marines]]. From 1973 to 1977, Captain Higgins served at the Staff Noncommissioned Officers Academy and [[Officer Candidate School (U.S. Marine Corps)|Officer Candidate School]], both in [[Marine Corps Base Quantico|Quantico]], Virginia. Returning to the [[Fleet Marine Force]] in 1977, Capt. Higgins was assigned to the [[2nd Marine Division (United States)|2nd Marine Division]] at [[Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune|Camp Lejeune]], North Carolina, where he again served as a rifle company commander with A Company, [[1st Battalion 2nd Marines|1st Battalion]], [[2nd Marine Regiment (United States)|2nd Marines]]. Upon promotion to major, he was reassigned as the [[Logistics]] Officer for [[2nd Marine Regiment (United States)|Regimental Landing Team 2]], [[4th Marine Amphibious Brigade]]. After completion of the Air Force Command and Staff College at [[Maxwell Air Force Base]] in 1980, designated a distinguished graduate, Higgins returned to [[Washington, D.C.]] where he served at Headquarters as a Plans Officer until his selection to the Office of the [[Secretary of Defense]]. During 1981 and 1982, he served as Military Assistant to the Special Assistant to the Secretary and Deputy Secretary of Defense, then as Assistant for Interagency Matters to the Executive Secretary for the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]. After graduation from the [[National War College]] in 1985, he returned to the Pentagon as the Military Assistant to the Secretary of Defense, where he served until he was transferred to his United Nations assignment in July 1987. He was promoted to Colonel on March 1, 1989, while in captivity. ==Capture and murder== [[File:William R. Higgins Headstone Detail Quantico National Cemetery.jpg|thumbnail|right|Headstone detail]] [[File:William_R._Higgins_Headstone_in_Quantico_National_Cemetery_Three_Quarter.jpg|thumbnail|right|William R. Higgins' headstone in Quantico National Cemetery]] On February 17, 1988, Higgins disappeared while serving as the Chief, Observer Group Lebanon and Senior Military Observer, United Nations Military Observer Group, [[United Nations Truce Supervision Organization]]. Higgins was driving alone on the coastal highway between [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]] and [[Naqoura]] in southern Lebanon, returning from a meeting with a local leader of the Amal movement, when he was pulled from his vehicle by armed men who it is suspected were affiliated with [[Hezbollah]].{{cite news |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0607/29/cp.01.html |title=CNN PRESENTS — Encore Presentation: Inside Hezbollah |accessdate=2008-09-03 |author= |last=Cooper |first=Anderson |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2006-07-29 |year= |month= |work= |publisher=CNN.com |pages= |language= |doi= |quote=Hezbollah is a suspect in the torture and murder of U.S. Colonel William Higgins. Higgins disappeared in 1988, while leading a U.N. observer group in south Lebanon. A year and a half later, this video appeared on television screens around the world. Higgins, badly beaten body, hanging from a rope. }}{{cite web|publisher=Military.com |title=Col. William R. 'Rich' Higgins: Spirit Of Murdered Marine Leader Lives On In USS Higgins |author=Bethanne Kelly Patrick |accessdate=2006-11-28 |url=http://www.military.com/Content/MoreContent?file=ML_higgins_bkp}}{{cite journal |title=Security Council demands immediate release of UN peace-keeper — Lt.-Col. William R. Higgins |journal=[[United Nations|UN]] Chronicle|date=December 1988|accessdate=2006-11-28 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1309/is_n4_v25/ai_6945292}} During his captivity, he was interrogated and tortured. As a reaction to his abduction, the [[United Nations Security Council]] adopted [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 618|Resolution 618]], demanding his release. A year and a half after his abduction, images of his body, hanged by the neck, were televised around the world from a videotape released by his captors. The exact date of Higgins' murder is uncertain; he was declared dead on July 6, 1990. His remains were recovered on December 23, 1991, by Major Jens Nielsen of the Royal Danish Army, who was attached to the United Nations Observation Group in Beirut.{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/missions/past/unogilbackgr.html |title=Lebanon{{mdash}}UNOGIL |work=United Nations Peacekeeping Missions |publisher=[[United Nations]] |accessdate=January 19, 2015}} Higgins' remains were found beside a mosque near a south [[Beirut]] hospital.Giandomenico Picco, Man Without a Gun, Times Books, New York (1999) His remains were interred at [[Quantico National Cemetery]], Triangle, Virginia, on December 30, 1991. ==Awards and honors== Higgins' military decorations include: the [[Defense Distinguished Service Medal]], [[Defense Superior Service Medal]], [[Legion of Merit]], [[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Star]] with [[combat "V"]], [[Purple Heart]], [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]], [[Navy Commendation Medal]] with gold star and combat "V", [[Combat Action Ribbon]], [[Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry]] with silver star, Staff Service Honor Medal, [[United Nations Medal]], and numerous unit commendations and campaign ribbons. On March 18, 1992, President George Bush awarded Higgins the [[Presidential Citizens Medal]] (posthumous). The medal was accepted by his wife, Robin, and daughter, Chrissy. Higgins was also survived by two sisters. On February 17, 1994, the [[Secretary of the Navy]] announced a new [[Arleigh Burke-class destroyer|''Arleigh Burke''-class]] guided missile destroyer would be named for Higgins. On October 4, 1997, the {{USS|Higgins|DDG-76}} was christened by Higgins' widow, [[Robin Higgins]] and commissioned on April 24, 1999.{{cite web|url=http://navysite.de/dd/ddg76.htm|title=USS Higgins (DDG 76)|work=navysite.de}} In April 2003, he was posthumously granted a [[Prisoner of War Medal]].See [http://www.mediafire.com/?d04qtp9a19f6ify memo from Secretary of the Navy to the Commandant of the Marine Corps, "Prisoner of War Medal ICO Colonel R. Higgins, USMC," dated January 16, 2003.]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} DoD General Counsel Judith A. Miller initially blocked the award in 1998 based on the claim that "circumstances do not appear to meet the criteria established by Congress for award of the Prisoner of War Medal." The Navy later overruled her after it was determined that the 1989 expansion of the eligibility criteria allowed the award.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafire.com/?0uxbx5vdc9t5vnu|title=Simple File Sharing and Storage.|work=MediaFire|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120905015647/http://www.mediafire.com/?0uxbx5vdc9t5vnu|archivedate=2012-09-05|df=}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== {{Portal|United States Marine Corps}} *{{cite web |url = https://wrc.navair-rdte.navy.mil/warfighter_enc/History/bios/higgins.htm |title = Colonel William R. Higgins, USMC |work = The War Fighters Encyclopedia |date = August 19, 2003 |accessdate = 2006-11-27 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20041105141256/https://wrc.navair-rdte.navy.mil/warfighter_enc/History/bios/higgins.htm |archivedate = November 5, 2004 |df = }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.ojc.org/higgins/ |title=Colonel Rich Higgins USMC - POW or Hostage? |author=Robin L. Higgins |date=February 7, 1998 |accessdate=2006-11-28}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |title=Patriot Dreams: The Murder of Colonel Rich Higgins |author=LtCol. Robin L. Higgins, USMC (Retired) |location=Quantico, VA: |publisher=The Marine Corps Association |isbn=0-940328-25-9 |year=1999}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Higgins, William R.}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:People from Danville, Kentucky]] [[Category:Military personnel from Louisville, Kentucky]] [[Category:Miami University alumni]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps colonels]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:American people taken hostage]] [[Category:Kidnappings by Islamists]] [[Category:American terrorism victims]] [[Category:American torture victims]] [[Category:Assassinated American people]] [[Category:Deaths by hanging]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Service Medal (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:American prisoners of war]] [[Category:Recipients of the Gallantry Cross (Vietnam)]] [[Category:American people murdered abroad]] [[Category:People murdered in Lebanon]] [[Category:Burials at Quantico National Cemetery]] [[Category:Presidential Citizens Medal recipients]] [[Category:Recipients of the Defense Superior Service Medal]] [[Category:American military personnel killed in action]] [[Category:Southern High School (Kentucky) alumni]] [[Category:National War College alumni]]
